For example, embryonic cells can pass through the G1 phase so quickly that it hardly exists, whereas neurons are arrested in the cell cycle and do not divide.

Mitosis occurs in all of the following types of cells EXCEPT

answers.C: <label>C. red blood cells</label>
answers.D: <label>D. pancreatic cells</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Mitosis occurs in all of the following type of cells except mature red blood cells. Mature red blood cells are short-lived and do not divide.

content:
The cell cycle is a series of events in the life of a dividing eukaryotic cell. It consists of four stages: G1, S, G2, and M. The duration of the cell cycle varies from one species to another and from one cell type to another. The G1 phase varies the most. For example, embryonic cells can pass through the G1 phase so quickly that it hardly exists, whereas neurons are arrested in the cell cycle and do not divide.

Since neurons are destined never to divide again, what conclusion can be made?

answers.A: <label>A. These cells will go through cell division.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. These cells will be permanently arrested in the G<sub><small>2</small></sub> phase.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. These cells will quickly enter the S phase.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Because neurons are not capable of dividing, it is reasonable to conclude that these cells will not complete the G1 phase. This is a reading comprehension question. The passage states that cells that do not divide are arrested at the G1 phase. Choice (A) is incorrect because these cells will not be committed to go through cell division. You can also eliminate (C) and (D), as the cells will not enter the G2 or S phase.

content:
The following graphs show the permeability of ions during an action potential in a ventricular contractile cardiac fiber. The action potential of cardiac muscle fibers resembles that of skeletal muscles.

Based on the graph, the resting membrane potential of the muscle fibers is closest to

answers.C: <label>C. 0 mV</label>
answers.D: <label>D. +70 mV</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A According to the graph, the resting membrane potential of the muscle fiber is close to -90mV.

content:
The following graphs show the permeability of ions during an action potential in a ventricular contractile cardiac fiber. The action potential of cardiac muscle fibers resembles that of skeletal muscles.

Which of the following statements is true concerning the initial phase of depolarization?

answers.A: <label>A. Voltage-gated K<sup><small>+</small></sup> channels open in the plasma membrane.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The concentration of Ca<sup><small>2+</small></sup> ions within the plasma membrane becomes more negative.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The membrane potential stays close to -40 mV.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The permeability of the sarcolemma to Na<sup><small>+</small></sup> ions increases.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Refer to the second graph about the membrane permeability of ions during a muscle contraction. During depolarization, the membrane is permeable to Na+. Choice (A) can be eliminated because the voltage-gated K+ channels do not open until after depolarization. Eliminate (B) because the concentration of Ca2+ does not become more negative. Choice (C) is also incorrect, as the membrane potential changes from -90 mV to +20 mV.

content:
The following graphs show the permeability of ions during an action potential in a ventricular contractile cardiac fiber. The action potential of cardiac muscle fibers resembles that of skeletal muscles.

In cardiac fibers, the duration of an action potential is approximately

answers.C: <label>C. 0.25 secs</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 0.30 secs</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Refer to both graphs in the passage. In cardiac fibers, the duration of an action potential—a neuronal impulse—is approximately 0.3 seconds.

content:
The following graphs show the permeability of ions during an action potential in a ventricular contractile cardiac fiber. The action potential of cardiac muscle fibers resembles that of skeletal muscles.

One major difference between the action potential of cardiac muscle fibers and the action potential of skeletal muscle fibers is that in cardiac muscle fibers

answers.A: <label>A. the membrane is permeable to Na<sup><small>+</small></sup>, not K<sup><small>+</small></sup></label>
answers.B: <label>B. voltage-gated K<sup><small>+</small></sup> channels open during depolarization, not repolarization</label>
answers.C: <label>C. depolarization is prolonged compared to that in skeletal muscle fibers</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the refractory period is shorter than that of skeletal muscle fibers</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C In cardiac muscle fibers, depolarization is prolonged compared to that in skeletal muscle fibers. Eliminate (A) because the membrane is permeable to both Na+ and K+. Choice (B) can also be eliminated; in cardiac muscle fibers, voltage-gated K+ channels open during repolarization. Finally, (D) is wrong because the refractory period is longer in cardiac muscle fibers compared to skeletal muscle fibers.

content:
The data below concerns the general animal body plan of five organisms.

The two most closely related organisms are

answers.C: <label>C. hagfish and eel</label>
answers.D: <label>D. sea anemone and salamander</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The two most closely related organisms are the two with the most shared derived characteristics.

content:
The data below concerns the general animal body plan of five organisms.

The correct order of evolution for the traits above is

answers.C: <label>C. jaws – walking legs – vertebral column</label>
answers.D: <label>D. vertebral column – jaws – walking legs</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Shared derived characteristics are newly evolved traits that are shared with every group on a phylogenic tree except for one. Vertebral columns are present in every group except for the sea anemone, so it must have evolved first. Walking legs are only found in the salamander, indicating that it most likely evolved most recently.

content:
The data below concerns the general animal body plan of five organisms.

Pre- and post-zygotic barriers exist that prevent two different species from producing viable offspring. All of the following are pre-zygotic barriers EXCEPT

answers.C: <label>C. sterility of offspring</label>
answers.D: <label>D. incompatible mating songs</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Pre-zygotic barriers to reproduction are those that prevent fertilization, so you can eliminate (A), (B), and (D). Choice (C) is an example of a post-zygotic barrier to reproduction.

content:
The data below concerns the general animal body plan of five organisms.

Birds and insects have both adapted wings to travel by flight. The wings of birds and insects are an example of

answers.C: <label>C. speciation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. mutation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Convergent evolution occurs when two organisms that are not closely related independently evolve similar traits, such as the wings of insects and birds. Divergent evolution occurs when two closely related individuals become more different over time and can lead to speciation.

content:
The following synthetic pathway of a pyrimidine, cytidine 5' triphosphate, CTP, begins with the condensation of two small molecules by the enzyme, aspartate transcarbamylase (ATCase).

Which of the following is true when the level of CTP is low in a cell?

answers.B: <label>B. The metabolic traffic down the pathway increases.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. ATCase is inhibited, which slows down CTP synthesis.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The final product of the pathway is reduced.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B When the level of CTP is low in a cell, the metabolic traffic down the pathway increases. This pathway is controlled by feedback inhibition. The final product of the pathway inhibits the activity of the first enzyme. When the supply of CTP is low, the pathway will continue to produce CTP.

content:
The following synthetic pathway of a pyrimidine, cytidine 5' triphosphate, CTP, begins with the condensation of two small molecules by the enzyme, aspartate transcarbamylase (ATCase).

This enzymatic phenomenon is an example of

answers.C: <label>C. dehydration synthesis</label>
answers.D: <label>D. photosynthesis</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B This enzymatic phenomenon is an example of feedback inhibition. Feedback inhibition is the metabolic regulation in which high levels of an enzymatic pathway's final product inhibit the activity of its rate-limiting enzyme. Transcription, (A), is the production of RNA from DNA. Dehydration synthesis, (C), is the formation of a covalent bond by the removal of water. In photosynthesis, (D), radiant energy is converted to chemical energy.

content:
The following synthetic pathway of a pyrimidine, cytidine 5' triphosphate, CTP, begins with the condensation of two small molecules by the enzyme, aspartate transcarbamylase (ATCase).

The biosynthesis of cytidine 5'-triphosphate requires

answers.A: <label>A. a ribose sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogen base</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a deoxyribose sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogen base</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a ribose sugar, phosphate groups, and a nitrogen base</label>
answers.D: <label>D. a deoxyribose sugar, phosphate groups, and a nitrogen base</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The biosynthesis of cytidine 5â€²-triphosphate requires a nitrogenous base, three phosphates, and the sugar ribose. Pyrimidines are a class of nitrogenous bases with a single ring structure. The sugar they contain is ribose, which is shown in the pathway diagram.

content:
Here is a sketch of a molecule of the sex hormone, testosterone, that is derived from cholesterol.

Which of the following statements best describes the action of this hormone on cells of the human gonads?

answers.A: <label>A. The hormone acts as the first messenger when it binds to and activates the G protein-coupled receptor on the surface of cells in the testes. This activates the mobile G protein located inside the cell.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The hormone enters cells in the testes by first binding with a membrane receptor, which causes a channel to open in the membrane, allowing the testosterone to flood into the cell.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The hormone readily passes through the cell membrane and binds to a receptor in the cytoplasm. The hormone and receptor then enter the nucleus and act as a transcription factor that turns on one or more genes.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The hormone binds with cAMP on the surface of the cell. Once attached to cAMP, the hormone enters the cell and initiates a signal transduction pathway.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The sex hormone testosterone is lipid soluble (hydrophobic) and dissolves directly through the cell membrane. Choices A and B correctly describe the action of a hydrophilic signal. Cyclic AMP is a secondary messenger found in the cytoplasm, not on the surface of a cell.

content: Mice are mammals. As such, they are endotherms. They maintain internal heat metabolically. A lizard is an ectotherm and gains its body heat from the environment. Which of the following graphs most accurately depicts this situation?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The body temperature of an ectotherm increases with the ambient temperature. A homeotherm or an endotherm can raise and lower its body temperature to maintain a steady body temperature.

content: Which of the following is a direct result of depolarizing the presynaptic membrane of an axon?

answers.A: <label>A. The postsynaptic cell produces an action potential.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Synaptic vesicles fuse with the presynaptic membrane.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Voltage-gated calcium channels in the membrane open.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Neurotransmitter is released into the synapse.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question focuses on the order of activity at the synapse. An electrical impulse travels down the axon, causing voltage-gated calcium channels in the presynaptic membrane to open. Calcium ions flood into the terminal branch. This causes presynaptic vesicles to fuse with the membrane and release their contents, neurotransmitter, into the synapse.

content:
There are two types of enzyme inhibition: competitive and noncompetitive. Competitive inhibitors compete with the substrate for one active site, while noncompetitive inhibitors bind to another part of the enzyme and alter its shape. Malonate is an inhibitor of the respiratory enzyme succinate dehydrogenase in the following reaction.

Which of the following choices best describes the best way to determine whether malonate is a competitive or a noncompetitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase?

answers.A: <label>A. In the presence of malonate, increase the concentration of succinate, the substrate. If the rate of reaction increases, then malonate is a competitive inhibitor.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. In the presence of malonate, increase the concentration of succinate, the substrate. If the rate of reaction increases, then malonate is a noncompetitive inhibitor.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Malonate can alternate between a competitive and noncompetitive inhibitor depending on what is required.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A coenzyme must be affecting the rate of the reaction.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) If malonate is a competitive inhibitor, it competes with the enzyme (succinate dehydrogenase) for succinate. If malonate is a noncompetitive inhibitor, increasing succinate will not increase the rate of reaction because the enzyme is being inhibited by malonate.

content: Water climate diagrams summarize the climate for a region. Average temperature is shown on the left axis, precipitation on the right axis, and months of the year on the x-axis. Assuming that a major limiting factor for plant growth is availability of water, choose the graph below that depicts the region with the best conditions for plant growth.
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This region has the most consistently warm temperature and the highest precipitation.

content:
Here is a graph showing the rate of photosynthesis of a green plant plotted against light intensity.

Which of the following statements accurately accounts for the shape of the graph?

answers.A: <label>A. The rate of photosynthesis stops increasing because chlorophyll molecules begin to decompose due to increased heat, not increased light.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The rate of photosynthesis slows as chlorophyll molecules, which are proteins, denature.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Photosynthesis ceases when protons are no longer released by the photolysis of water.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The rate of photosynthesis increases until the light-harvesting apparatus in the thylakoid membranes become saturated and cannot make use of additional light.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The graph flattens out but doesn't decrease. Therefore, photosynthesis is still going on. That indicates that choices A, B, and C cannot be correct.

content: The lac operon is found only in prokaryotes and consists of structural genes and a promoter and operator. Which of the following statements explains why we study the lac operon?

answers.A: <label>A. It represents a principal means by which gene transcription can be regulated.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It explains how baby mammals utilize lactose from their mothers as they nurse.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It illustrates how RNA is processed after it is transcribed.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It illustrates possible control of the cell cycle and may lead to an understanding of cancer.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Remember that operons are found in prokaryotes, not higher organisms. However, higher animals may utilize a similar mechanism. For the same reason, you must eliminate Choice B. Operons are a means of controlling transcription of genes, whereas Choice C focuses on what happens after transcription. Operons have nothing to do with the cell cycle.

content:
Here is the simplified equation for photosynthesis:

6CO2 + 12 H2O → C6H12O6 + 6H2O + 6O2

Which of the following choices correctly traces the atom identified with an arrow?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The process of hydrolysis releases oxygen from water into the air.

content: The plasma membrane is selectively permeable and regulates what enters and leaves a cell. It consists of a phospholipid bilayer embedded with proteins. Which of the following statements about the membrane is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. Carbon dioxide is a polar molecule and readily diffuses through the hydrophilic layers of the membrane.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Starch readily diffuses across the membrane into the liver, where it is stored as glycogen.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Aquaporins are special water channels in the plasma membrane that facilitate the uptake of large amounts of water without the expenditure of energy.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Oxygen passes through the cristae of mitochondria mainly through ATP synthase channels.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Carbon dioxide is a balanced and nonpolar molecule that can readily diffuse through the membrane. Starch is too large to diffuse through a membrane. Only protons pass through mitochondrial membranes.

content: Active transport involves the movement of a substance across a membrane against its concentration or electrochemical gradient. Active transport is mediated by specific transport proteins and requires the expenditure of energy. Which of the following statements describes an example of active transport?

answers.A: <label>A. Glucose is transported across some membranes by carrier proteins down a concentration gradient.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Freshwater protists such as amoeba and paramecia have contractile vacuoles that pump out excess water.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Countercurrent exchange in the capillaries of fish gills enables fish to absorb large amounts of oxygen from the surrounding water where oxygen levels are low.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A red blood cell will lyse (burst) if placed into a hypotonic solution because large amounts of water flood into the cell.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Whenever a pump is involved, the mechanism is active transport. Glucose is always transported by either simple diffusion or facilitated diffusion. However, neither process requires the expenditure of energy. Choices C and D refer to passive transport.

content:
Here is a sketch of an animal cell.

Which of the following statements is correct?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Structure B is the Golgi apparatus, which packages and secretes proteins made by the ribosomes in the E.R. The centrioles shown as structure A consist of microtubules. Structure C is a lysosome. Strucure D consists of ribosomes on the E.R.

content:
Chronically high levels of glucocorticoids can result in obesity, muscle weakness, and depression. This looks like several diseases but actually is only one, Cushing syndrome. Excessive activity of either the pituitary or the adrenal gland can cause the disease. To determine which gland has abnormal activity in a particular patient, doctors use the drug dexamethasone, a synthetic glucocorticoid that blocks ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) release.

Based on the graph, which gland is affected in the patient with Cushing syndrome and what is the reasoning behind your answer?

answers.A: <label>A. The pituitary, because although ACTH is blocked, the pituitary is still sending a signal to the adrenal glands.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The pituitary, because blocking ACTH has no effect on cortisol levels.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The adrenal gland, because the pituitary is prevented from stimulating the adrenal glands, and yet cortisol levels are still high.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The adrenal gland, because the pituitary is sending a signal to the adrenal gland and the adrenal glands have stopped producing cortisol.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The patient is still producing too much cortisol even though the pituitary is not sending a signal to the adrenal glands. ACTH, which would normally stimulate the adrenal to release cortisol, is blocked by the dexamethasone. If the adrenals were healthy, they should not be producing anything. Unfortunately, they are. Compare the patient with the normal person.

content:
Here is the final reaction in the citric acid cycle. It shows the regeneration of oxaloacetate.

After studying the reaction, determine which of the following statements is correct.

answers.A: <label>A. The enzyme malate dehydrogenase is allosteric.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The reaction is exergonic; the released energy is absorbed by NAD<sup><small>+</small></sup>.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The reaction is a reduction reaction.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. NAD<sup><small>+</small></sup> is oxidized into NADH.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Energy is released, and NAD+ binds to hydrogen released by malate.

content: Which of the following statements about the DNA in one of your liver cells is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. Your liver cells contain the same DNA as your white blood cells.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Most of the DNA in your liver cells will be transcribed but not translated.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Most of the DNA in your liver cells will be transcribed in the nucleus and translated in the cytoplasm.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. DNA in your liver cells contains genes unique to storing glycogen, while other cells do not contain those genes.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) All cells in your body contain the same genes; the difference is which ones are turned on and which are turned off. Also, less than 3% of all a human cell's DNA is transcribed and translated.

content:
Two genes (B and E) determine coat color in Labrador retrievers. Alleles B and b code for how much melanin is present. The dominant allele B codes for black fur, the recessive allele b codes for brown hair. A second gene consisting of two alleles, E and e, codes for the deposition of pigment in the hair. In this case, the alleles for pigment deposition (E or e) are said to be epistatic to the gene that codes for black or brown pigment. If the dominant allele (E) is not present, regardless of the genotype at the black/brown locus, the animal's fur will be yellow.

Which of the following statements is correct about the genetics of coat color in Labradors?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The trait for deposition of pigment (E) is epistatic to the presence of color (B/b). If there is no dominant trait for deposition, the animal will be yellow or golden. An animal with the genotypes BBEe or BbEe is black. An animal with the genotypes bbEE or bbEe is brown. However, the genotype BBee results in a yellow dog.

content: Within a cell, the amount of protein synthesized using a given mRNA molecule depends in part on which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. DNA methylation suppresses the expression of genes.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Transcription factors mediate the binding of RNA polymerase and the initiation of transcription, which will determine how much protein is manufactured.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The speed with which mRNA is degraded will determine how much protein is synthesized.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The location and number of ribosomes in a cell will solely determine how much protein is synthesized.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Choices A and B refer to transcription of DNA. However, the question asks about protein manufactured from an RNA molecule.

content:
Oxygen is carried in the blood by the respiratory pigment hemoglobin, which can combine loosely with four oxygen molecules, forming the molecule oxyhemoglobin. To function properly, hemoglobin must bind to oxygen in the lungs and drop it off at body cells. The more easily the hemoglobin binds to oxygen in the lungs, the more difficult the oxygen is to unload at the body cells. Here is a graph showing two different saturation-dissociation curves for one type of hemoglobin at two different pH levels.

Based on your knowledge of biology and the information in this graph, which statement about the hemoglobin curves is correct?

answers.C: <label>C. In an acidic environment, hemoglobin drops off oxygen more easily at body cells.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The line to the right shows a lower affinity for oxygen. CO2 dissolved in water produces carbonic acid. What this graph demonstrates is that the blood near respiring cells, which release carbon dioxide, make the surrounding area acidic. This acidic environment causes hemoglobin to release its oxygen to the cells where it is needed.

content: Banana plants, which are triploid, are seedless and therefore sterile. Which is the most likely explanation for this phenomenon?

answers.A: <label>A. Because they are triploid, bananas cannot generate gametes because homologous pairs cannot line up during meiosis.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Because they are triploid, there are no male or female banana plants.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Because they are triploid, bananas cannot generate homologous pairs during mitosis.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Because they are triploid, bananas cannot carry out crossing-over.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) No evidence is provided in the question about bananas not having separate sexes. Meiosis, not mitosis, produces gametes. It is true that there can be no crossing-over if there is no synapsis (when homologous pairs line up to exchange DNA), but gametes could form. There would not be any variation in the gametes.

content:
Animals maintain a minimum metabolic rate for basic functions such as breathing, heart rate, and maintaining body temperature. The minimum metabolic rate for an animal at rest is the basal metabolic rate (BMR). The BMR is affected by many factors, including whether an animal is an ectotherm or endotherm; its age and sex; and size and body mass. Here is a graph that shows the relationship of BMR per kilogram of body mass to body size for a group of mammals.

Which statement correctly describes the relationship between BMR and body mass?

answers.A: <label>A. The relationship between BMR and body mass is a direct one. The larger the body mass the higher the BMR is and the greater the breathing rate is.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The relationship between BMR and body mass is a direct one. The larger the body mass the higher the BMR is and the lower the breathing rate is.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The relationship between BMR and body mass is inversely proportional. The larger the body mass, the lower the BMR is and the lower the breathing rate is.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The larger the animal, the faster the heart rate and breathing rate both are.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The energy to maintain each gram of body mass is inversely related to body size. This graph describes a relationship between X and Y that is inversely proportional. When the relationship is directly proportional the line goes diagonally from the lower left to upper right. Each gram of mouse requires 20 times as many calories as a gram of elephant even though the whole elephant uses more calories than a whole mouse. The higher the metabolic rate, the higher the oxygen and food requirement per unit of body mass.

content:
Here is a graph that depicts a first exposure to antigen A on Day 1 with a subsequent, primary immune response. A second exposure to antigen A on Day 30 results in a secondary immune response due to the presence of circulating memory cells that release antibodies against antigen A. There is also a first exposure to antigen B on
Day 30.

Which of the following graphs accurately depicts the immune response to antigen B and the reason for it?

(A)

(B)

(C)

(D)
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This may seem tricky, but Choice B is correct. Immune responses are specific. Each challenge with a new antigen results only in a primary immune response for that antigen.

content: Incomplete dominance and epistasis are two terms that define genetic relationships. Which of the following statements best describes the differences or similarities between the two terms?

answers.A: <label>A. Both terms describe inheritance controlled by the interaction of multiple alleles at different loci.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Both terms describe inheritance controlled by the interaction of multiple genes at different loci.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Incomplete dominance describes the interaction of two genes at different loci; epistasis describes the interaction of two alleles.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Incomplete dominance describes the interaction of two alleles on one gene; epistasis describes the interaction of two genes and their respective alleles.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This is a fact.

content: Before the human genome was sequenced by the Human Genome Project, scientists expected that they would find about 100,000 genes. In fact, they discovered that humans have only about 24,000 genes. How can we exhibit so many different traits from so few genes?

answers.A: <label>A. Modification of histone proteins usually increases the function of genes.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Epigenetics enables one gene to produce many different traits.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. This is proof that pseudogenes and introns are expressed.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A single gene can produce more than one trait because of alternative splicing</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Modification of histone proteins, as in methylation, silences genes. Epigenetics refers to the expression of a trait due to non-DNA factors. Pseudogenes and introns are not expressed.

content: Which of the following statements about the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. They provide the carbon that becomes incorporated into sugar.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. They produce PGA, which is converted to glucose by carbon fixation in the light-independent reactions.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Water is split apart, providing hydrogen ions and electrons to NADP for temporary storage.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They occur in the stroma of chloroplasts.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) All the other choices refer to the light-independent reactions.

content: The acrosome and cortical reactions that occur immediately after fertilization ensure which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. The sperm will fertilize the ovum.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The zygote will begin to divide normally.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. One and only one sperm will fertilize the egg.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The zygote will not divide into two embryos, producing twins.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The acrosome reaction enables the sperm to penetrate the coat surrounding the ovum. The cortical reaction ensures that a fertilization membrane forms and prevents another sperm from penetrating the egg. The cortical reaction is responsible for a slow block to polyspermy.

content: Which aspects of cell structure best reveals the unity of all life?

answers.A: <label>A. All cells are surrounded by a plasma membrane.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. All cells have at least one nucleus.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. All cells carry out cellular respiration in mitochondria.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The surface-to-volume ratio of all cells is the same.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Prokaryotes do not have internal membranes. They do not have a defined nucleus. Instead, they have DNA in a nucleoid region. All cells carry out cellular respiration, but they do not necessarily do it in mitochondria. The surface-to-volume ratio of cells varies with the cell's size. Smaller cells have a greater surface-to-volume ratio.

content:
Refer to the codon table for the following question.

Here is a small stretch of mRNA that would be translated at the ribosome:

. . . AUG CUG AAA UCAGGG . . .

Suppose a spontaneous mutation altered the boldface A and changed it to a U.
What effect, if any, would this have on the protein formed?

answers.A: <label>A. Because of redundancy in the code, there would be no change in the protein formed.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The polypeptide would not form because translation would stop at UAA.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Translation would continue and a polypeptide would form because AUG codes for start as well as for methionine.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) UAA codes for a stop sequence. Translation would cease at that point in the process.

content: Stretching out from the equator is a wide belt of tropical rain forests that are being cut down to provide exotic woods for export to the U.S. and to make land available to graze beef cattle. Which of the following statements is a negative consequence of clear-cutting the tropical rain forests?

answers.A: <label>A. Indigenous populations will have access to modern conveniences.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There will be less precipitation in those clear-cut areas.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. U.S. markets will have access to less expensive beef.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Deforestation will allow more sunlight to penetrate areas that were kept dark by dense vegetation.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Rain forests are responsible for the cycle of rain, absorption of water by roots, transpiration from leaves, cloud formation, and rain again. Without trees to absorb and evaporate water, the region will dry up and perhaps become a desert under a hot sun.

content: Mosquitoes resistant to the pesticide DDT first appeared in India in 1959 within 15 years of widespread spraying of the insecticide. Which of the following statement best explains how the resistant mosquitoes arose?

answers.A: <label>A. Some mosquitoes experienced a mutation after being exposed to DDT that made them resistant to the insecticide. Then their population expanded because these moquitoes had no competition.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Some mosquitoes were already resistant to DDT when DDT was first sprayed. Then their population expanded because all the susceptible mosquitoes had been exterminated.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. DDT is generally a very effective insecticide. One can only conclude that it was manufactured improperly.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Although DDT is effective against a wide range of insects, it is not effective against mosquitoes.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Resistance to a certain chemical arises because exposure to the chemical kills all the insects except the ones that are already resistant to it. The resistant population is selected for in this way and reproduces a new population in which all the individuals are resistant.

content: DNA sequences in many human genes are very similar to the corresponding sequences in chimpanzees. Which statement gives the most likely explanation of this fact?

answers.A: <label>A. Humans evolved from chimpanzees millions of year ago.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Chimpanzees evolved from humans millions of years ago.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Humans and chimpanzees evolved from a recent common ancestor—about 6 million years ago.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Humans and chimpanzees evolved from a distant common ancestor about 4 billion years ago.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Humans and chimps share an ancestor that walked upright about 6–7 million years ago.

content:
Two ecologists, Peter and Rosemary Grant, spent thirty years observing, tagging, and measuring finches (a type of bird) in the Galápagos Islands. They made their observations on Daphne Major—one of the most desolate of the Galápagos Islands. It is an uninhabited volcanic cone where only low to the ground cacti and shrubs grow. During 1977, there was a severe drought and seeds of all kinds became scarce. The small, soft seeds were quickly eaten by the birds, leaving mainly large, tough seeds that the finches normally ignore. The year after the drought, the Grants discovered that the average width of the finches' beak had increased.

Which of the following statements best explains the increase in beak size?

answers.A: <label>A. Finches with bigger and stronger beaks were able to attack and kill the finches with smaller beaks.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Finches with bigger beaks were larger animals with stronger wings that could fly to other islands and gather a wide variety of seeds.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. During the drought, the finches' beaks grew larger to accommodate the need to eat tougher seeds.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Finches with larger beaks were able to eat the tougher seeds and were healthier and reproduced more offspring that inherited the trait for wider beaks.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This is classic Darwinian evolutionary theory—the survival of the best adapted.

content:
Two ecologists, Peter and Rosemary Grant, spent thirty years observing, tagging, and measuring finches (a type of bird) in the Galápagos Islands. They made their observations on Daphne Major—one of the most desolate of the Galápagos Islands. It is an uninhabited volcanic cone where only low to the ground cacti and shrubs grow. During 1977, there was a severe drought and seeds of all kinds became scarce. The small, soft seeds were quickly eaten by the birds, leaving mainly large, tough seeds that the finches normally ignore. The year after the drought, the Grants discovered that the average width of the finches' beak had increased.

Which of the following statements best explains the mechanism behind the change in beak size?

answers.A: <label>A. A new allele appeared in the finch population as a result of a mutation.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A change in the frequency of a gene was due to selective pressure from the environment.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A new trait appeared in the population because of recombination of alleles.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A new trait appeared in the population because of genetic drift.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Choices A, C, and D all have the same problem. A new trait may have appeared by a single mutation, by recombination of alleles, or by genetic drift. However, that does not explain how the birds, on average, came to have longer beaks.

content:
Answer the following two questions based on this pedigree for the biochemical disorder known as alkaptonuria. Affected individuals are unable to break down a substance called alkapton, which colors the urine black and stains body tissues. Otherwise, the condition is of no consequence. Males are shown as squares, females as circles. Afflicted individuals are shown in black. If there is a carrier condition, it is not displayed.

Which of the following best states the pattern of inheritance shown in the pedigree?

answers.C: <label>C. The trait is autosomal dominant.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The trait is autosomal recessive.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Look at individuals 1 and 2. Neither has the condition, but they have a daughter with the condition. Sex-linked dominant and autosomal dominant are eliminated because neither parent has the condition. Sex-linked recessive is also eliminated because if the father passed the trait to his daughter, he would have to have the condition. For the daughter to have the condition, she would have had to inherit two affected X chromosomesâ€”one from each parent.

content:
Answer the following two questions based on this pedigree for the biochemical disorder known as alkaptonuria. Affected individuals are unable to break down a substance called alkapton, which colors the urine black and stains body tissues. Otherwise, the condition is of no consequence. Males are shown as squares, females as circles. Afflicted individuals are shown in black. If there is a carrier condition, it is not displayed.

Which of the following statement is supported by the information given in the pedigree?

answers.A: <label>A. The P generation mother is X-X.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The P generation father is X-Y.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. If parents 1 and 2 in row II have another child, the chance that the child would be afflicted with alkaptonuria is 25%.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The genotype of woman 1 is X-X.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Since the trait is inherited as autosomal recessive, individuals 1 and 2 are each hybird. The chance that any child of theirs will have the condition is 25%.

content:
Sea otters in the North Pacific are a keystone species. That means they are not abundant in a community. However, they do exert major control over other species in the community. Here is a food chain in which the sea otter is a keystone species.

Kelp → Sea urchin → Sea otter → Orca

Here are two graphs showing the populations of sea otters and sea urchins from 1970 to 2000.

In the late 1990s, orcas, which are active hunters of sea otter, moved into the area. Which of the following graphs correctly shows the kelp population from 1970 to 2000?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) When orcas moved into the area, the population of sea otters declined. This caused the population of sea urchins to increase and, ultimately, the kelp population to decline.

content:
Four vials were set up to investigate bacterial transformation. Vials 1 and 2 each contained E. coli bacteria that had been made competent and had then been mixed with a plasmid containing the gene for ampicillin (pAMP) resistance. Vials 3 and 4 both contained E. coli that had also been made competent but had not been mixed with a plasmid. Each vial of bacteria was poured onto a nutrient agar plate. Vials 1 and 3 were poured onto plates that contained the antibiotic ampicillin. Vials 2 and 4 were poured onto plates that did not contain ampicillin.
This figure shows what the nutrient agar plates looked like. The shaded plates represent extensive growth, and the dots represent individual bacterial colonies.

Plates that have only ampicillin-resistant bacteria growing on them include which of the following?

answers.C: <label>C. Plate 3 only</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Plates 1 and 3 only</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The few colonies growing on Plate 1 consist of bacteria that have taken up the plasmid and are resistant to ampicillin. Plate 2 consists of both antibiotic-resistant bacteria as well as nonresistant bacteria. There is no antibiotic in the agar on Plate 2 to distinguish the two bacteria.

content:
Four vials were set up to investigate bacterial transformation. Vials 1 and 2 each contained E. coli bacteria that had been made competent and had then been mixed with a plasmid containing the gene for ampicillin (pAMP) resistance. Vials 3 and 4 both contained E. coli that had also been made competent but had not been mixed with a plasmid. Each vial of bacteria was poured onto a nutrient agar plate. Vials 1 and 3 were poured onto plates that contained the antibiotic ampicillin. Vials 2 and 4 were poured onto plates that did not contain ampicillin.
This figure shows what the nutrient agar plates looked like. The shaded plates represent extensive growth, and the dots represent individual bacterial colonies.

Which of the following statements explains why there was no growth on Plate 3?

answers.C: <label>C. Those bacteria were not transformed.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The bacteria culture died because they have a short life span.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The bacteria on Plate 3 were not transformed. That means they did not uptake a plasmid and were not resistant to antibiotic. There is antibiotic in the agar on that plate, which killed the nontransformed bacteria.

content:
Four vials were set up to investigate bacterial transformation. Vials 1 and 2 each contained E. coli bacteria that had been made competent and had then been mixed with a plasmid containing the gene for ampicillin (pAMP) resistance. Vials 3 and 4 both contained E. coli that had also been made competent but had not been mixed with a plasmid. Each vial of bacteria was poured onto a nutrient agar plate. Vials 1 and 3 were poured onto plates that contained the antibiotic ampicillin. Vials 2 and 4 were poured onto plates that did not contain ampicillin.
This figure shows what the nutrient agar plates looked like. The shaded plates represent extensive growth, and the dots represent individual bacterial colonies.

Which of the following statements best explains why there were fewer colonies on Plate 1 than on Plate 2?

answers.A: <label>A. The bacteria on Plate 2 did not transform.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There was no antibiotic in the agar in Plate 2 that would have restricted growth of bacteria.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The transformation of bacteria on Plate 2 was more successful.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The bacteria on Plates 1 and 2 were not taken from the same culture.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The few colonies growing on Plate 1 consist of bacteria that have taken up the plasmid and are resistant to ampicillin. Plate 2 consists of both antibiotic-resistant bacteria as well as nonresistant bacteria. There is no antibiotic in the agar on Plate 2 to distinguish the two bacteria.

content:
Four vials were set up to investigate bacterial transformation. Vials 1 and 2 each contained E. coli bacteria that had been made competent and had then been mixed with a plasmid containing the gene for ampicillin (pAMP) resistance. Vials 3 and 4 both contained E. coli that had also been made competent but had not been mixed with a plasmid. Each vial of bacteria was poured onto a nutrient agar plate. Vials 1 and 3 were poured onto plates that contained the antibiotic ampicillin. Vials 2 and 4 were poured onto plates that did not contain ampicillin.
This figure shows what the nutrient agar plates looked like. The shaded plates represent extensive growth, and the dots represent individual bacterial colonies.

In a variant of this experiment, the plasmid contained GFP (green fluorescent protein) in addition to ampicillin resistance. Which of the following plates would have the highest percentage of bacteria that would fluoresce?

answers.C: <label>C. Plate 3 only</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Plate 4 only</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) There would be fluorescent bacteria on both Plates 1 and 2. However, 100% of the bacteria on Plate 1 would fluoresce while only a percentage of the bacteria on Plate 2 would do so.

content:
Here is a sketch of a neuromuscular junction in a patient with an autoimmune disease. Acetylcholine (ACh) is the stimulatory neurotransmitter.

Which of the following predicts what will happen in the continued presence of the antibodies?

answers.B: <label>B. The amount of neurotransmitter being released will decrease.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The number of action potentials in the motor neuron will decrease.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Antibodies will destroy the postsynaptic receptors, and the muscle response will diminish.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) In an autoimmune disease, the immune system mistakenly attacks its own body structures. The antibodies attack the postsynaptic muscle receptors, not the neuron function.

content: Which cell type is most likely involved in storage?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This happens to be a fat-storing cell from an animal. It has the obvious trait of a large vacuole. Choice A is a white blood cell. Choice B is a sclerenchyma cell from a plant. Choice C is a neuron.

content: In 1953, Stanley Miller, while working under the guidance of Harold Urey at the University of Chicago, carried out a series of experiments with substances that mimicked those of early Earth. His experimental setup yielded a variety of amino acids that are found in organisms alive on Earth today. The purpose of these experiments best supports which of the following hypotheses?

answers.A: <label>A. The basic building blocks of life originated in outer space and came to Earth carried by comets or meteorites.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The molecules necessary for life to develop were located in deep-sea vents.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The molecules necessary for life to develop could have formed under the conditions of the early Earth.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The molecules necessary for life on Earth were self-replicating proteins, just like the ones produced in Miller's experiments.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Some scientists believe that some complex molecules necessary for life on Earth might have come from outer space. That might be true. However, the purpose of Miller's experiment was to demonstrate that the molecules necessary for life to develop could have formed under the conditions of the early Earth. He did not succeed in demonstrating that the first molecules were self-replicating.

content:
The graph on the left (A) shows an absorption spectrum for chlorophyll a extracted from a plant. The graph on the right (B) shows an action spectrum from a living plant, with wave lengths of light plotted against the rate of photosynthesis as measured by release of oxygen.

Which statement best explains the difference between the two spectra?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Graph A shows the absorption spectrum for chlorophyll that was extracted from a living plant. Once separated from the grana and stroma, chlorophyll by itself cannot carry out photosynthesis.

content:
Cystic fibrosis is the most common inherited disease in the U.S. Among people of European descent, 4% are carriers of the recessive cystic fibrosis allele. The most common mutation in individuals with cystic fibrosis is a mutation in the CFTR protein that functions in the transport of chloride ions between certain cells and extracellular fluid. These chloride transport channels are defective or absent in the plasma membranes of people with the disorder. The result is abnormally high concentration of extracellular chloride that causes the mucus that coats certain cells to become thicker and stickier than normal. Mucus builds up in the pancreas, lungs, digestive tract, and other organs. This leads to multiple effects, including poor absorption of nutrients from the intestines, chronic bronchitis, and recurrent bacterial infections.

Scientific work has been carried out to measure where the relative amounts of CFTR protein are localized in the affected cells.

After studying the graph, which of the following statements about CFTR protein is correct?

answers.C: <label>C. CFTR protein does not fold properly after it is synthesized.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. CFTR protein is not being packaged in the cytoplasm.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Ribosomes produce protein for export. Once synthesized, the protein is packaged into vesicles in the Golgi for secretion. The graphs show that the amount of CFTR is high where synthesis occurs in the E.R. and low in the vesicles and Golgi. So the protein was synthesized in the ribosomes but not packaged.

content:
Cystic fibrosis is the most common inherited disease in the U.S. Among people of European descent, 4% are carriers of the recessive cystic fibrosis allele. The most common mutation in individuals with cystic fibrosis is a mutation in the CFTR protein that functions in the transport of chloride ions between certain cells and extracellular fluid. These chloride transport channels are defective or absent in the plasma membranes of people with the disorder. The result is abnormally high concentration of extracellular chloride that causes the mucus that coats certain cells to become thicker and stickier than normal. Mucus builds up in the pancreas, lungs, digestive tract, and other organs. This leads to multiple effects, including poor absorption of nutrients from the intestines, chronic bronchitis, and recurrent bacterial infections.

From the description of cystic fibrosis above, which of the following statements is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. The disease is similar to cancer in that it has both an environmental and a genetic cause.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Cystic fibrosis is an example of a genetic disease caused by polygenic inheritance because several genes must be mutated in order for the disease to occur.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Cystic fibrosis is an example of pleiotropy because one mutated gene causes multiple effects.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A person who has one cystic fibrosis allele will have the disease.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Cystic fibrosis is solely an inherited disease. No environmental component causes the disease. It is an autosomal recessive disease. In order to have the disease, a person must have inherited two mutated genes, one from each parent. Polygenic inheritance involves the inheritance of several genes. An example is height, skin, or hair colorâ€”any trait where a tremendous variety occurs in a population.

content:
Referring to the simplified reaction of cellular respiration shown here, which of the following statements is correct?

C6H12O6 + 6O2 → 6CO2 + 6H2O + energy
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This equation shows cellular respiration. The definition of reduction is the gain of electrons or hydrogen. Free oxygen on the left side of the equation exists by itself, but on the right side it has combined with hydrogen. Also, remember that during cellular respiration, oxygen combines with protons and electrons during oxidative phosphorylation.

content: Based on the cladogram, which of the following is NOT true?

answers.B: <label>B. Mammals and amphibians are more closely related than mammals and birds.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Ancestor 2 lived before ancestor 3; and we do know when that was.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Lungfishes and amphibians share a common ancestor.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This cladogram does not have a time scale attached to it. All we can say about any clade or lineage is that one evolved earlier or later than another. A cladogram is constructed to show the development of different traits and the lineage of related organisms that evolved with that trait.

content:
On Andros Islands in the Bahamas, populations of mosquito fish, Gambusia hubbsi, colonized a series of ponds. These ponds are no longer connected. However, the environments are very similar except that some ponds contain predatory fish, while others do not. In high predation ponds, selection has favored the evolution of a body shape that enables rapid bursts of speed. In low predation ponds, another body type is favored—one that is well-suited to swim for long periods of time.

When scientists brought together sample mosquito fish from the two types of ponds, they found that the females mated only with males that had the same body type as their own. Which of the following statements best describes what happened to the mosquito fish as evidenced by the mating choice in the female fish?

answers.C: <label>C. Allopatric isolation brought about reproductive isolation.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Sympatric isolation brought about reproductive isolation.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Allopatric isolation refers to isolation due to geographic separation. Sympatric isolation refers to isolation caused by something other than geography, such as polyploidy. These fish clearly exhibited allopatric isolation because the two populations lived in different ponds with different selective factors. The pressure for selection came from the predatory fish. After years of being separated, the two fish populations could no longer mate. Therefore, allopatric isolation brought about reproductive isolation.

content:
From 1972 to 2004, researchers studying the greater prairie chicken observed that a population collapse mirrored a reduction in fertility as measured by the hatching rate of eggs. Comparison of DNA samples from the Jasper County, Illinois, population with DNA from feathers in a museum collection showed that genetic variation had declined in the studied population. The researchers translocated prairie chickens from Minnesota, Kansas, and Nebraska into the Illinois prairie chicken population in 1992 and found that the hatching rate in Illinois prairie chickens changed. Here is a graph of the data.

Which of the following statements most accurately explains what happened to the studied population of prairie chickens after translocation and why?

answers.A: <label>A. The hatching rate increased because genetic variation declined.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The hatching rate increased because genetic variation increased.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The hatching rate decreased because genetic variation decreased.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The hatching rate decreased because the translocated animals were invasive and grew to dominate the population.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Prior to translocation, the chickens had become inbred, diversity had decreased, and fertility had declined.

content: Which of the following statements about the immune system is NOT correct?

answers.A: <label>A. A lymphocyte has receptors for many different antigens.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. An antigen can have different epitopes.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Dendritic cells are antigen-presenting cells.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. T cells attack infected body cells.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Notice the question says NOT. A lymphocyte has receptors for only one type of antigen. The other statements are correct.

content:
In a study of dusty salamanders, Desmognathus ochrophaeus, scientists brought individuals from different populations into the laboratory and tested their ability to mate and produce viable, fertile offspring. Here is the graph of the data.

The degree of reproductive isolation is represented by an index ranging from 0 (no isolation) to 2 (complete isolation).

Which of the following statements best describes the evolutionary history of dusty salamanders?

answers.A: <label>A. Mutation alone caused the two populations to diverge.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Both mutation and genetic drift cause the two populations to diverge.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Both mutation and genetic drift caused the two populations to become separate species after they were separated by great distance.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Reproductive isolation between the two populations increases as the distance between them increases.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The question does not reveal anything about mutation or genetic drift. The point here is that in this case, divergence is a function of geographic distance.

content: Which of the following statements best describes what a Barr body is and its significance?

answers.A: <label>A. It is an inactivated Y chromosome and results in a man being sterile.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It is an inactivated Y chromosome, and the person who has it appears female.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It is an inactivated X chromosome and results in females with half their cells having one X inactivated and the other half of their cells having the other X inactivated.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It is an inactivated X chromosome and results in females who are sterile.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Every cell in the mammalian females has two X chromosomes, but one of them will be deactivated in every cell. Which one of the two becomes inactive occurs randomly and independently in each embryonic cell. So, females are considered to be mosaics because they contain two types of cells, in terms of what genes a cell contains. This does not apply to men because men only have one X chromosome in each cell.

content:
Scientists carried out a series of experiments to study innate immunity in fruit flies. They began with a mutant fly strain in which a pathogen is recognized but the signaling that would normally trigger an innate response is blocked. As a result, the flies did not make any antimicrobial peptides (AMP). The researchers then genetically engineered some of the mutant flies to express significant amounts of a single AMP, either defensin or drosomycin. They then infected the flies with a fungus, Neurospora crassa, by shaking anesthetized flies for 30 seconds in a Petri dish containing a sporulating fungal culture. The 6-day survival rate was monitored and recorded.

Here is a graph displaying some data from the experiment.

KEY:

Which of the following statements is supported by the data?

answers.A: <label>A. Each AMP provided minimal immunity against fungal infection.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Both AMPs provided better immunity than did either one alone.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Drosomycin provided immunity against the fungal infection.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There was no control in this experiment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The survival of mutant flies + drosomycin was greater than mutant flies + defensin. Two controls, A and D, were included in this experiment.

content:
An experiment was carried out with guppies, which are brightly colored, popular, aquarium fish. Three hundred guppies were added to 12 large pools. Cichlids, a voracious predator, were added to 4 of the pools. Killifish that rarely eat guppies were added to 4 other pools. No other fish were added to the last 4 pools. After 16 months, a time period that represents 10 generations for guppies, all the guppies were analyzed for size and coloration. Here are the data.

Which of the following statements is supported by the data?

answers.A: <label>A. Cichlids were an agent of selection, eating the more visible, brightly colored guppies.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Killifish were an agent of selection, eating the more visible, brightly colored guppies.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Guppies, as a group, experienced change in coloration, from brightly colored to dull in order to survive.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Individual guppies experienced a mutation that caused a change in coloration and enabled them to avoid being eaten.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Killifish do not eat guppies, but cichlids do. So cichilds were the agent of selection. No organism or population changes in order to survive. If individuals are not adapted, they die. No individual changes during its lifetime. Rather, the frequency of a particular trait in a population may change.

content:
An experiment was carried out with guppies, which are brightly colored, popular, aquarium fish. Three hundred guppies were added to 12 large pools. Cichlids, a voracious predator, were added to 4 of the pools. Killifish that rarely eat guppies were added to 4 other pools. No other fish were added to the last 4 pools. After 16 months, a time period that represents 10 generations for guppies, all the guppies were analyzed for size and coloration. Here are the data.

Which of the following statements best expresses the point of this experiment?

answers.A: <label>A. Mutations can be brought about by the environment.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Agents of selection are not always readily apparent.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Evolution does not always require millions of years.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The evolution in this population—the change in frequency of the trait for brightly colored spots—occurred rapidly, within 16 months. Evolution does not always require millions of years. The rate of change is a function of the pressure from the environment to change.

content: In the Tularosa Basin of New Mexico are black lava formations surrounded by light-colored sandy desert. Pocket mice inhabit both areas. Dark-colored ones inhabit the lava formations, while light-colored mice inhabit the desert. Which of the following statements is correct about this scenario?

answers.A: <label>A. The two varieties of mice descended from a recent common ancestor.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The mouse population was originally one population that diverged into two species because of mutations.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Selection favors some phenotypes over others.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Originally the mice were all dark colored. As the lava decomposed into sand, the color of some mice changed because that color was favored in that environment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The question does not give you enough background to determine anything more than to say that some traits are favored more than others in a particular environment.

content: What is the best explanation for the fact that tuna, sharks, and dolphins all have a similar streamlined appearance?

answers.A: <label>A. They all share a recent common ancestor.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. They all sustained the same set of mutations.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. They acquire a streamlined body type to survive in their particular environment.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The streamlined body has a selective advantage in that environment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Once again, the environment provides the direction for evolutionary change. Tuna and sharks are fish; dolphins are mammals. Fish and mammals do not share a recent common ancestor.

content: Which of the following statements is not correct about lipids?

answers.A: <label>A. Lipids consist of fatty acids and glycerol.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The molecules of a saturated fatty acid are packed so close together that they form a solid at room temperature.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The head of a phospholipid is hydrophobic, and the tails are hydrophilic.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The head of a phospholipid is hydrophilic, and the tails are hydrophobic. The phosphate head is charged and therefore polar.

content:
Here is a sketch of prokaryotic DNA undergoing replication and transcription simultaneously.

If 1 is thymine, what is a?

answers.C: <label>C. Cytosine</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Uracil</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) First orient yourself in the drawing. The process at the top of the sketch is replication; the bottom is transcription. So if 1 is thymine, then its complement, I, is adenine. Therefore, if I is adenine, then its base pair is thymine.

content:
Here is a sketch of prokaryotic DNA undergoing replication and transcription simultaneously.

If 4 is adenine, what is D?

answers.C: <label>C. Cytosine</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Uracil</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The bottom of the diagram represents transcription. Therefore, if 4 is adenine, then D is its complement in RNA, which is uracil.

content: Yeast cells carry out both aerobic and anaerobic respiration. A yeast cell that is fed on glucose is moved from an aerobic to an anaerobic environment. Which of the following statements is correct and gives the correct reason for it?

answers.A: <label>A. The cell dies because it cannot make ATP.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The cell would need to consume glucose at a much greater rate because aerobic respiration is much more efficient as compared with anaerobic respiration.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The cell would need to consume another food source other than glucose because it will not be able to make adequate ATP with only glucose.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The cell will begin to divide rapidly because larger cells require more oxygen and glucose than smaller ones.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Anaerobic respiration is much less efficient at making ATP than is aerobic respiration. Glycolysis produces only 2 net ATPs from each molecule of glucose. The yeast can survive on glucose alone.

content:
Intact chloroplasts are isolated from dark-green leaves by low-speed centrifugation and are placed into six tubes containing cold buffer. A blue dye, DPIP, which turns clear when reduced, is also added to all the tubes. Then each tube is exposed to different wavelengths of light. A measurement of the amount of decolorization is made, and the data are plotted on a graph. Although the wavelengths of light vary, the light intensity is the same.

Which statement below best describes the results of the experiment?

answers.A: <label>A. The lower the wavelength of light, the greater the rate of photosynthesis.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The highest wavelengths of light provide the fastest rate of photosynthesis.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The highest rate of photosynthesis results from exposure to two different wavelengths of light.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The greatest reduction in DPIP occurs at 550 nm light intensity.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The greatest reduction (change in color of DPIP) occurs at 650 nm + 700 nm of light. The steeper the decline of the graph, the greater the reduction of DPIP.

content:
Intact chloroplasts are isolated from dark-green leaves by low-speed centrifugation and are placed into six tubes containing cold buffer. A blue dye, DPIP, which turns clear when reduced, is also added to all the tubes. Then each tube is exposed to different wavelengths of light. A measurement of the amount of decolorization is made, and the data are plotted on a graph. Although the wavelengths of light vary, the light intensity is the same.

What is the best explanation for the results in Question 61?

answers.A: <label>A. 650 nm and 700 nm of light have the greatest penetrating power.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The photosynthetic pigments in the experiment do not absorb light in the 650 nm and 700 nm range.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Only wavelengths of 650 nm and 700 nm are reflected by the chlorophyll.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The chloroplasts have two photosystems that absorb light in different wavelengths.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The shorter the wavelength of light, the greater the penetrating power. Therefore, light with a wavelength of 550 nm has the greatest penetrating power. Light that is reflected is not absorbed.

content:
A group of scientists wished to learn about the energy efficiency of different modes of locomotion. They studied the literature that was based on accurate measurements and produced this graph based on the data they analyzed.

Which of the following statement accurately describes what the scientists discovered?

answers.A: <label>A. An animal with a large body mass expends more energy per kilogram of body mass than a small animal, regardless of the type of locomotion.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Swimming has to overcome drag as well as gravity.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Running is the least energy-efficient means of locomotion.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) According to the data, an animal with a small body mass expends more energy per kilogram of body mass regardless of the type of locomotion. Swimming is the most efficient means of locomotion. Swimming does not have to overcome gravity; the swimmer is supported by the water.

content:
Oxygen is carried in the blood by the respiratory pigment hemoglobin, which can combine loosely with four oxygen molecules to form the molecule oxyhemoglobin. To function properly, hemoglobin must bind to oxygen in the lungs and drop it off at body cells. The more easily the hemoglobin bonds to oxygen in the lungs, the more difficult for the hemoglobin to unload the oxygen at the body cells. Here is a graph showing two different saturation-dissociation curves for one type of hemoglobin at two different pH levels.

Based on your knowledge of biology and the information in this graph, which statement about the hemoglobin curves is correct?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This graph is focused on the strength of the bond between Hb and oxygen at pH 7.2 and pH 7.4. At a lower at pH, which is more acidic, the attachment is weaker. This makes sense because as cells carry out cellular respiration, they release CO2, which makes the blood more acidic. The blood pH changes from normal 7.4 to the more acidic 7.2. At pH 7.2, the Hb can release more of its oxygen where it is needed, at the cells.

content: The geneticist Mary Lyon hypothesized the existence of structures visible just under the nuclear membrane in mammals, which were later named Barr bodies. Which of the following statement is NOT correct about Barr bodies?

answers.A: <label>A. In the early female embryo, one copy of the X chromosome becomes inactivated in every body cell.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The same chromosome in every cell of a normal female is inactivated.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A male with the XXY genotype will have one Barr body.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Barr bodies consist of highly methylated DNA.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Notice that the question says NOT. In each cell in a woman's body, one of the X chromosomes is inactivated. One X is inactivated in half of her cells and the other X in the other half of her cells. The other statements are correct about Barr bodies.

content: Energy is harvested during cellular respiration in stages. Which of the following correctly states which phase of cellular respiration harvests the most energy and the correct explanation why?

answers.C: <label>C. The most energy is released during oxidative phosphorylation because in addition to the phosphorylation of ADP into ATP, all the potential energy held in NADH and FADH is transferred to ATP.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Although it is true that during the Krebs cycle pyruvate is completely broken down to CO2, the most energy from cellular respiration is released during oxidative phosphorylation, when all the energy stored in NADH and FADH2 from previous stages of cellular respiration is released.

content:
The following reaction occurs in the citric acid cycle. Study the reaction as it is shown here.

Which of the following statements is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. This is part of the reaction that produces pyruvate.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The reaction is an example of negative feedback.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The reaction is an oxidation reaction.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The reaction occurs in the cristae membrane.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Oxidation is the loss of electrons or of hydrogen. You can see that hydrogen has been lost by the succinate to form fumacate. If this is part of the citric acid cycle, then pyruvate is the starting point of this reaction, not the product. The citric acid cycle produces CO2 and ATP. Feedback mechanisms are complex. This is certainly not one. The stem of the question states that this is part of the citric acid cycle, which occurs in the inner matrix of the mitochondria, not the cristae membrane.

content: Which of the following statements is correct about a man who has hemophilia and whose wife does not have the disease and who does not have any relatives with the disease?

answers.A: <label>A. All his daughters will have the disease.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. All his sons will have the disease.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. All his sons will be carriers.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. All his daughters will be carriers.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The father's genotype is X-Y; the mother's is XX. In this case, the father passes his X-gene to all their daughters. So all the daughters inherit the X-gene. He passes his Y chromosome to his sons.

content: Identify the phase of meiosis when recombination occurs, and state the reason for your decision.

answers.A: <label>A. Picture 1, because sister chromosomes are lined up on the metaphase plate.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Picture 1, because homologous pairs are lined up on the metaphase plate.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Picture 2, because homologues are paired up in synapsis.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Picture 3, because homologous pairs are exchanging genetic material.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Recombination occurs when homologous pairs bind together during synapsis and crossing-over occurs. Picture 1 is in metaphase. Synapsis and crossing-over have already occurred. The homologous pairs are about to separate. Picture 2 shows prophase. Synapsis is occurring, and crossing-over can occur at this point. Picture 3 shows sister chromatids lined up on the metaphase plate. There can be no crossing-over because there is only one chromosome.

content: A rooster with gray feathers and a hen with the same phenotype produce 17 gray, 7 black, and 8 white chicks. What is the simplest explanation for the inheritance of these colors in chickens?

answers.A: <label>A. The trait for gray is epistatic over the trait for black.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The trait for gray is epistatic over the trait for white.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The traits for black and white color demonstrate incomplete dominance.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The traits for black and white color demonstrate codominance.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) When you see a blending of the parental phenotypes in the offspring, you are dealing with incomplete dominance. The genotype of the black animals is BB. The genotype of the white animals is WW. The genotype of the gray animals is BW.

content: Hydrangea flowers have one gene for flower color. Plants of the same genetic variety have flowers that range in color from blue to pink with the color varying due to the type of soil in which they are grown. Which of the following statement best explains this phenomenon?

answers.A: <label>A. The alleles for flower color show incomplete dominance where neither trait is dominant; expression of the genes shows a blending of traits.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The alleles for flower color are codominant; both traits show depending on the environment.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. In this case, the environment alters the expression of a trait.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The genes for flower color show polygenic inheritance.</label>
