explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) A soil with acid pH causes the flowers to be pink; a basic soil gives rise to blue flowers. Polygenic inheritance is characteristic of traits like skin color, hair color, and height that exist in a complete spectrum. ABO blood type is an example of codominance because both A and B genes show.

content:
A female fruit fly hybrid for both gray body (Gg) and normal wings (Nn) is crossed with a male with black body (gg) and vestigial wings (nn): GgNn Ã— ggnn.
The F1 results of the cross are shown in the chart below.

Which of the following statements best explains the results?

answers.A: <label>A. The two alleles for body color and wing structure are located on separate chromosomes and assort independently.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The two alleles for body color and wing structure are located on separate chromosomes and assorted independently, but there was some crossing-over.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The two alleles are linked, located on the same chromosome, immediately next to one another, and inherited together.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The two alleles are linked and located on the same chromosome but are far apart and experienced some crossing-over.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) By analyzing the F1 results, you see that there is almost a 50-50 ratio of gray normal to black vestigial.The 50-50 ratio of those traits tells you that the traits are linked. If the body is gray, the wings are normal; if the body is black, the wings are vestigial. However, a small variation from the expected values occurred. Those numbers, 190 and 184, are due to crossing-over. Genes that are very close together usually are inherited together. So these genes must be far apart on the same chromosome.

content:
A female fruit fly hybrid for both gray body (Gg) and normal wings (Nn) is crossed with a male with black body (gg) and vestigial wings (nn): GgNn Ã— ggnn.
The F1 results of the cross are shown in the chart below.

Which of the following sketches depicts the most likely location of the alleles for body color and wing shape?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The two genes are linked and far apart on the same chromosome.

content: Which of the following is an example of a coupling of an exergonic reaction with an endergonic one?

answers.A: <label>A. Unicellular organisms that live in freshwater, such as amoeba, must pump out excess water using their contractile vacuoles.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The enzyme lactase binds with lactose to produce molecules of glucose and galactose.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The flow of electrons down an electron transport chain in mitochondria powers the pumping of protons against a gradient into the outer compartment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The coupling of exergonic and endergonic reactions is an important biochemical strategy. The exergonic flow of electrons in the cristae membrane of mitochondria provides the energy to pump protons across the cristae membrane and maintain a gradient.

content: Which of the following statements best describes what this cell will accomplish as part of the immune system?

answers.A: <label>A. It will secrete a chemical that will form holes in the pathogen.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It will produce antibodies against the antigen it is engulfing.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It will circulate in the bloodstream for a lifetime and will be able to identify the antigen in the future.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It will present pieces of the antigen on its surface membrane.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) A macrophage is an antigen-presenting cells (APC). It will alert the adaptive immune system about a particular invader.

content: A researcher is experimenting with nerve transmission using neurons from a giant squid. At the beginning of the experiment, the axon is at rest and has a threshold measured at –70 mV at 37oC. The axon receives one stimulus that triggers one action potential in the axon. Subsequent stimuli are much stronger. Which of the following statements explains what happens when several strong stimuli are experienced by the axon?

answers.A: <label>A. The axon becomes hyperpolarized to –90 mV.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The axon becomes hyperpolarized to –50 mV.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The strength of the action potential becomes greater.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The frequency of the action potential increases.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The action potential is an all-or-nothing response. It either happens or it does not. It doesn't change strength. With a stronger stimulus, only the frequencies of the response increases. The axon does not become hyperpolarized; it depolarizes. If the axon at rest is at –90 mV, the hyperpolarization will measure at –100 mV, for example, not at 50 mV.

content: The frequency of a particular allele in a population of 1,000 birds in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is 0.3. If the population remains in equilibrium, what would be the expected frequency of that allele after 500 years?

answers.A: <label>A. It will increase if the allele is favorable or will decrease if it is unfavorable for individuals in that population.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Not enough information is provided to determine if the frequency of the allele will remain the same or change.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The frequency of the allele will remain at 0.3 because the population is at Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The frequency of the allele will remain the same; this is an example of the bottleneck effect.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The definition of Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is that the allelic frequencies will not change. If one trait becomes advantageous and the allelic frequency changes, then the population is no longer in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

content:
You carry out an experiment to study transpiration in plants using a two-week-old bean plant. You set up a potometer by cutting the stem of a plant and securing it into clear flexible tubing that has been tightly connected to a calibrated pipette. Water fills the potometer from the plant stem to the tip of the pipette.
You measure water loss from your potometer at 10-minute intervals and plot your data on the graph as Line B.

You then explore what happens if you expose the plant to different conditions. Which of the following statements is correct based on proposed changes to the potometer?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Green plants reflect green light; they do not absorb it and cannot use it as an energy source. Placing a plastic bag over the leaves will decrease transpiration, resulting in Line C. Placing a fan near the plant will increase transpiration, causing Line A.

content:
You carry out an experiment to study transpiration in plants using a two-week-old bean plant. You set up a potometer by cutting the stem of a plant and securing it into clear flexible tubing that has been tightly connected to a calibrated pipette. Water fills the potometer from the plant stem to the tip of the pipette.
You measure water loss from your potometer at 10-minute intervals and plot your data on the graph as Line B.

Which of the following is NOT correct about transpiration in plants?

answers.A: <label>A. Water moves upward from the roots to the shoots in the xylem by active transport from an area of high osmotic potential to an area of low osmotic potential.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Plants lose water through stomates in their leaves.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The movement of water through a plant is facilitated by the physical and chemical properties of the water itself.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Placing a container of water between the light source and the plant is necessary to prevent the introduction of heat as a second variable in the experiment.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Notice the question states NOT. All the other answer choices are correct. Water moves up the plant through the xylem by passive transport because of the physical properties of water. Choice D refers to the use of a heat sink, which is necessary in this experiment to make sure that the temperature does not rise during the experiment. If the temperature did rise, it would constitute another variable in the experiment.

content: When the first tiny prokaryotic cell took up residence inside a larger prokaryotic cell, it heralded the advent of the eukaryotic cell and led to an explosion of new life on Earth. Since then, most cells on Earth have internal organelles. Which of the following best summarizes an advantage of having internal membranes and organelles?

answers.B: <label>B. Even though prokaryotes do not have mitochondria, they contain structures that carry out the same function.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Organelles separate specific reactions in the cell and increase metabolic efficiency.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Compartmentalization enables prokaryotes to reproduce more quickly.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The importance of internal organelles is that they compartmentalize the cell so that widely different reactions can all occur at the same time, each in their own space.

content: Many different fermentation pathways occur in different organisms in nature. For example, skeletal muscle cells convert pyruvate into lactic acid when no oxygen is present. Yeast cells can produce alcohol and carbon dioxide under the same circumstances. However, regardless of the specific reactions, the purpose of glycolysis is an important one. Which statement best describes the importance of glycolysis?

answers.A: <label>A. It produces large amounts of ATP by substrate level phosphorylation.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It reoxidizes NADH so that glycolysis can continue.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It produces pyruvate, which is the raw material for oxidative phosphorylation.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It occurs in the cytoplasm.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Glycolysis would cease if there were not a constant supply of NAD+ to bind to hydrogen. Glycolysis produces pyruvate, which is the raw material for the citric acid cycle, not oxidative phosphorylation. Glyocolysis does occur in the cytoplasm, but that is not important.

content: Human DNA and the DNA of a banana are 50% identical. Which statement best explains this fact in terms of what you know about the evolution of life on Earth?

answers.A: <label>A. Humans evolved from an organism that resembled a banana more than a billion years ago.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. All organisms on Earth evolved from an ancestral eukaryotic cell 2 billion years ago.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Humans and bananas evolved from a recent common ancestor within the last 6 million years.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Bananas and humans have experienced thousands of mutations that have made us appear so very different from each other.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Earth is about 4.5 billion years old. The planet took about 1 billion years to cool down and be stable enough for life to evolve, and for the first cell—a prokaryotic cell—to develop. About 2 billion years ago, the first eukaryotic cell evolved. We have fossil evidence of that. Humans, bananas, and all other eukaryotic cells evolved from some ancestral eukaryotic cell. That is why there are basic similarities among all living things.

content: Which of the following principles is NOT part of Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection?

answers.A: <label>A. Evolution is a gradual process that occurs over a long period of time.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Mutations are the main source of all variation in a population.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Organisms will overpopulate area, giving rise to competition.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Mutations were not discovered until around 1900 when DeVries, while working with polyploid plants, coined the term. Darwin could not explain the origin of all the variation he saw. This lack of mechanism was the weakest part of his theory.

content: Which of the following statements is supported by the information presented in the graph, which shows a comparison of two regions in Oregon, one deforested and the other undisturbed?

answers.A: <label>A. Roots of plants are efficient at absorbing nitrates from the soil.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Variation in the amount of nitrate in stream water is due to periods of intense rain.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Replanting trees after an area has been clear-cut can prevent nitrate runoff into rivers.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The presence of trees in an area causes an increase of nitrates in the soil.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) After deforestation, the nitrate runoff onto the rivers increased. There is no evidence presented that trees were replanted. Choice D is clearly false.

content:
Here is a food web for a habitat that is threatened by developers who will remove three-fourths of the grasses in the area on which the mice and rabbits feed.

Which of the following statements describes what will most likely happen to the wildlife in the area?

answers.A: <label>A. The hawk will begin to eat frogs instead of snakes and mice.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Since three trophic levels are shown in the food web, 75% of the organisms in this food web will die.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Based on the number of trophic levels, about 25% of the mice and rabbits will die.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The hawk population will decrease.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Even though numbers are mentioned in the question, they are not relevant. There is no way to determine if hawks will begin to eat frogs, which is niche displacement. You can deduce only the obvious.

content: The pH of two lakes is measured. Lake A has a pH of 8.0; Lake B has a pH of 6.0. Which of the following statements is correct about these lakes?

answers.D: <label>D. The pH of both lakes will decrease in response to acid rain.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Acid rain is caused by the accumulation of sulfuric, sulfurous, nitric, and nitrous acids in the air from the burning of fossil fuels. A pH of 6.0 is 100 times more acidic than pH 8. The hydrogen ion concentration of pH 6 = 1 × 10–6M.

content: The BCL-2 gene codes for a protein that normally inhibits apoptosis. In some cases, the BCL-2 gene is mutated and becomes activated inappropriately. Cells with this mutated, overexpressed gene fail to undergo apoptosis; they continue to divide and form cancerous tumors. The mutated gene causes many cancers, including lymphoma and breast, colon, and prostate cancers. Oblimersen is a drug now in clinical trials that is an antisense RNA. It binds to BCL-2 mRNA and inactivates it. Which of the following sketches accurately demonstrates the action of the antisense drug Oblimersen?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The drug Oblimersen is an antisense RNA. Therefore, it binds to the overexpressed RNA and prevents it from translating. Theoretically, Oblimersen should work in preventing cancer.

content:
Figure 1 shows the growth of the filamentous green algae Spirogyra in a flask of sterilized pond water that contains nitrate. If phosphate is added to the flask as shown, the growth curve changes to that shown in Figure 2.

Which of the following graphs is the best prediction of the algae growth if more nitrate (NO3) is added along with the phosphate?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The extra nitrate does not contribute any more to the algae growth than the initial increase. Phosphate is the main contributing factor to algae growth.

content: Which of the following statements correctly characterizes an autoimmune disease?

answers.A: <label>A. T cells attack healthy body cells.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. An aneurysm is a weakness in the wall of a blood vessel that causes it to balloon out. The vessel can rupture and cause a hemorrhage.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Several factors cause hypertension: smoking, being overweight, lack of physical activity, and too much salt in the diet.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Alzheimer's disease is caused by the buildup of plaque within the brain, causing brain cells to die.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This is an accurate description of an autoimmune disease.

content: Apoptosis, which is programmed cell death, is a necessary process in living organisms. Which of the following is NOT correct about apoptosis?

answers.B: <label>B. A particular cell dies when it is no longer needed by the organism.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A cell carries out apoptosis when too many mutations have accumulated.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Plant cells carry out apoptosis as a defense measure in cells that have been infected by parasites.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Apoptosis is anything but random. It is controlled by both internal and external signals that lead a class of enzymes called caspases to assist in the digesting of a cell marked for apoptosis.

content: African lungfish often live in small, stagnant, freshwater pools. With reduced gills, they differ from other fish in that they breathe air. They also differ in that they release the nitrogen waste urea instead of ammonia. Which of the following statements correctly explains how this is an advantage for lungfish?

answers.A: <label>A. Urea is insoluble in water and sinks to the bottom of the small pools. Thus the poisonous substance is isolated from the fish.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Ammonia, which is highly toxic, would endanger lungfish that inhabit the small pools.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Other fish in the small pools can use urea as an energy source.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The highly toxic urea makes the pool uninhabitable to competitors.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Uric acid is the nonsoluble nitrogen waste, not urea. Ammonia is the most toxic nitrogen waste, not urea.

content: During oxidative phosphorylation, the energy needed to drive ATP synthesis comes from one source. Which of the following statements states the immediate source of that energy?

answers.A: <label>A. Electrons flow down an electron transport chain as they are attracted to oxygen.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The transfer of a phosphate group to ADP is exergonic.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The bonding of electrons to oxygen at the end of the chain releases energy.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The proton gradient across the membrane where the ATP synthase is embedded represents potential energy.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Protons flowing down a gradient through ATP synthase provide energy to phosphorylate ADP into ATP. Energy from the exergonic flow of electrons to oxygen provides the energy to pump protons across the cristae membrane and form a gradient.

content: Which of the following statements about cellular respiration is correct?

answers.B: <label>B. Protons are pumped through ATP synthase by active transport.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The final electron acceptor of the electron transport chain is NAD<sup><small>+</small></sup>.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. ATP is formed because an endergonic reaction is coupled with an exergonic reaction.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The exergonic flow of electrons in the electron transport chain of mitochondria provides the energy to establish a proton gradient. Most CO2 released from cellular respiration comes from the citric acid cycle. Protons flow through the ATP synthase down a gradient, not by active transport.

content: The light reactions of photosynthesis supply the Calvin cycle with which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. The light reactions provide oxygen for the light-independent reactions.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. ATP and NADPH provide the power and raw materials for the Calvin cycle.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Water entering the plant through the roots provides hydrogen directly to the Calvin cycle.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Oxygen is needed to attract electrons down an electron transport chain in the light-dependent reactions. Water entering the plant through the roots ultimately provides hydrogen for the Calvin cycle, but first it is needed in the light-dependent reactions. CO2 enters the plant through the stomates; it is not released by the light-dependent reactions.

content:
Here is a sketch showing cyclic photophosphorylation in the grana of plant cells.

Which of the following statements about this process is correct, and what is the reason for it?

answers.A: <label>A. It is similar to oxidative phosphorylation in cellular respiration because its function is to generate ATP.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It is similar to glycolysis because it involves an electron transport chain.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It is the opposite of cellular respiration because it releases oxygen rather than utilizes it.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It is the opposite of the citric acid cycle because ATP is utilized, not produced.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The only thing this process produces is ATP. No NADPH or oxygen is released. The function of this process is to provide ATP for the Calvin cycle, which uses enormous quantities of ATP.

content: Which of the following statements about lipids is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. Unsaturated fatty acids are linked to heart disease.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Lipids make up most cell surface receptors.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Phospholipids are water soluble.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Steroids are lipids that consist of glycerol and fatty acids.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Saturated fatty acids are linked to heart disease. Proteins make up most cell surface receptors. Steroids are lipids but are not made of glycerol and fatty acids like typical lipids.

content: Unlike large populations, small populations are vulnerable to various processes that draw populations down an extinction vortex toward smaller and smaller populations until no individuals survive. Which of the following statements correctly identifies the factors that endanger a population?

answers.A: <label>A. Inbreeding and loss of genetic variation threaten a population.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Migration of new individuals into the population threatens a population.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Mutation reduces the health of a population.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Breeding with individuals from a different population may cause the extinction of the first population due to a decrease in diversity.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) All the other choices promote outbreeding, the introduction of new genes into a population.

content: Which of the following statements about the immune system is NOT correct?

answers.A: <label>A. Innate immunity, also known as the adaptive immune response, relies on circulating phagocytes engulfing foreign substances.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Adaptive immunity is a slower response than innate immunity.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Innate immunity activates a humoral response.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Dendritic cells are antigen presenting cells.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Innate immunity and adaptive immunity do not refer to the same thing. Innate immunity is the inborn, nonspecific first and second lines of defense. Adaptive immunity is specific and involves antigens and antibodies. Adapative immunity follows innate immunity and is slower. Adaptive immunity involves the humoral (antibody) response. Dendritic cells are antigen-presenting cells.

content: The disaccharide lactose is available to E. coli in the human colon if the host drinks milk. Digestion of lactose into glucose and galactose begins with the hydrolysis of lactose by the enzyme β-galactosidase, which is encoded by gene Z in the lac operon. Which of these diagrams correctly depicts the lac operon when lactose is being utilized?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) In order for transcription of a gene or genes to occur, RNA polymerase must bind to a promoter. In Choices A and B, the repressor is bound to the operator, which excludes RNA polymerase from binding to the promoter and prevents transcription. Choice D does not make any sense because RNA polymerase does not bind to the operator. It's a matter of specificity, like a lock and key.

content: Which of the following statements explains how a point mutation can have no negative impact in the protein formed from a sequence in DNA?

answers.A: <label>A. The first codon of a gene is always AUG, a leader sequence; a mutation in that sequence will have no effect on the protein produced.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Several codons code for the same amino acid.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. DNA polymerase and DNA ligase carry out excision repair before transcription.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. RNA processing will repair point mutations before mRNA leaves the nucleus.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) A mutation in AUG would have disastrous consequences because translation could not begin. Choice C refers to what happens after transcription. RNA processing occurs after transcription.

content: When DNA replicates, each strand of the original DNA molecule is used as a template for the synthesis of a second, complementary strand. Which of the following sketches most accurately illustrates the synthesis of a new DNA strand at the replication fork?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The new strand is built 5′ to 3′, and the Okazaki fragments form, moving away from the replication fork.

content: Which of the following statements correctly describes what happens to the preRNA during RNA processing?

answers.A: <label>A. Introns are removed in the nucleus. A 5′ cap and the poly-A tail are added after the preRNA leaves the nucleus.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Introns are removed and both a 5′ cap and a poly-A tail are added before the preRNA leaves the nucleus.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Exons are removed and a 5′ cap is added before the preRNA leaves the nucleus. After leaving the nucleus, the poly-A tail is added.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Point mutations are repaired, exons are removed, and both a 5′ cap and a poly-A tail are added before the preRNA leaves the nucleus.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) RNA processing occurs before the preRNA transcript leaves the nucleus. Introns, which are intervening sequences, are removed. Exons are the expressed sequences, which are the genes or coding regions.

content: Which of the following statements most accurately explains what EcoR1 is?

answers.A: <label>A. It is a bacterium that lives in the human large intestine.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It is a type of DNA used extensively in research.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Other restriction enzymes are BamHI and HindIII. They are all used extensively in biotechnology. The name of the bacteria that lives in the human intestine is E. coli. The name of the best-studied bacteriophage is lambda (Î») phage.

content: snRNPs are most closely associated with which of the following?

answers.C: <label>C. Replication of DNA</label>
answers.D: <label>D. RNA processing</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) snRNPs stands for small ribonucleoproteins. They form a complex with spliceosomes on a preRNA molecule complex and excise the introns during RNA processing.

content: Which of the following is correct about vaccination?

answers.A: <label>A. It increases the number of different receptors that recognize a particular pathogen.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It increases the number of different macrophages specific to the antigen.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It increases the number of epitopes that the immune system can recognize.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It increases the number of lymphocytes with receptors that can recognize and bind to the antigen.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Vaccinations are given to immunize against a particular antigen. They increase the number of a particular white blood cell that recognizes and binds to a particular antigen.

content:
A scientist wanted to understand the role of the gonads and their hormones in the development of the sex of an individual. He carried out an experiment with rabbit embryos while they were still in the mothers' uterus at a stage before sex differences were observable. He surgically removed the portion of each embryo that would develop into ovaries or testes. When the babies were born, he made note of their chromosome sex and the sexual differentiation of the genitals. Here are his data.

Which of the following statements is a correct conclusion to draw from this experiment?

answers.A: <label>A. In rabbits, female development requires a hormonal signal from the female gonad.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. In rabbits, male development requires a hormonal signal from the male gonad.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. In mammals, gonad development is triggered by sex hormones.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. In mammals, all embryos develop male gonads without signals to do otherwise.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Without the signal from the gonads to develop into a male, the rabbit remains a female.

content:
A scientist wanted to understand the role of the gonads and their hormones in the development of the sex of an individual. He carried out an experiment with rabbit embryos while they were still in the mothers' uterus at a stage before sex differences were observable. He surgically removed the portion of each embryo that would develop into ovaries or testes. When the babies were born, he made note of their chromosome sex and the sexual differentiation of the genitals. Here are his data.

What is the correct prediction if the researcher were to replace the surgically removed gonad with a crystal of testosterone?

answers.A: <label>A. The chromosomal male embryo would develop testes.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The chromosomal female embryo would develop testes.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Both chromosomal male and female embryos would develop male gonads.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Neither chromosomal male nor female embryos would develop male gonads.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The testosterone would send the signal that the male gonad would have sent.

content: Which of the following statements about meiosis is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. The daughter cells are genetically identical to the parent cells.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. DNA replication occurs before meiosis I and meiosis II.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The number of chromosomes is reduced.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The point of meiosis is variation. Daughter cells are different from the parent cells as well as each other. Homologues pair during prophase I, not prophase II. DNA replication occurs before meiosis I only.

content: Which of the following is correct about organisms that are the first to colonize a habitat undergoing ecological succession?

answers.A: <label>A. They are the fiercest competitors in the area.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. They maintain the habitat as it is for their own kind.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. They change the habitat in a way that makes it more habitable for other organisms.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They are small invertebrates.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Pioneer organisms colonize an area that is not habitable by other organisms and alter it over time in a way that makes the area habitable for other organisms. Pioneer organisms are producers, such as lichens that are symbiontsâ€”an intertwined relationship of a fungus and an algae.

content:
In the microscopic world of a pond, paramecia are ferocious predators that prey on smaller protists. In a classic experiment, two species of paramecia were grown separately in culture. The species in culture A was P. caudatum. The species in culture B was P. bursaria. Then the two species were combined in one culture dish (culture C).

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the growth pattern of the two populations combined in culture C?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Almost by definition, the two species do not share a niche because both populations are surviving. However, the environment has limited resources. In fact, the S-shaped growth curve shown in all three of these graphs is called a logistic growth curve. It is characteristic of some microorganisms under conditions of limited resources.

content: When driving from east to west in the U.S. from a forest ecosystem to grasslands, trees gradually give way to grasses. Which of the following is the critical factor responsible for this shift?

answers.C: <label>C. Availability of water</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Length of growing season</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Oxygen and sunlight do not vary when driving from forest to grasslands. The limiting factor for plant growth is water. Less precipitation occurs in the grasslands than in the forests.

content: Which of the following is an example of a cline?

answers.A: <label>A. The hybrid tomato plant is stronger and produces better fruit than the pure genotype.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There are two distinct varieties in one population of snail that inhabits an island in the Pacific Ocean.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Males of some species have long antlers to fight other males for females.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. In one species of rabbit, the ones that evolved in the cold, snowy north are white, while the ones that evolved in the south are brown.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Choice A refers to hybrid vigor. Choice B refers to polymorphism. Choice C refers to survival of the fittest and sexual selection.

content: Which of the following statements is NOT correct about ancient Earth?

answers.A: <label>A. Earth was formed about 4? billion years ago.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Amino acid synthesis could have been stimulated by volcanic eruption.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The first cells formed about 3? billion years ago, according to the fossil record.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The presence of free oxygen facilitated the rapid formation of organic molecules.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) There was no free oxygen in ancient Earth's atmosphere. In fact, given the strong oxidative nature of oxygen, had it been available, organic molecules that formed in early Earth might not have remained as they did.

content:
Intact chloroplasts are isolated from dark-green leaves by low-speed centrifugation and placed into six tubes containing cold buffer. A blue dye, DPIP, which turns clear when reduced, is also added to all the tubes. The amount of decolorization is a function of how much reduction and, therefore, how much photosynthesis occurs. Each tube is exposed to different wavelengths of light. A measurement of the amount of decolorization is made, and the data are plotted on a graph. Although the wavelengths of light vary, the light intensity in each tube is the same.

Which statement below best explains the results of this experiment and the reason for it?

answers.A: <label>A. The rate of photosynthesis is highest when a tube is exposed to light in the 550 nm range because that wavelength of light contains the greatest amount of energy.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The rate of photosynthesis is highest when exposed to light in the 550 nm range because that wavelength of light contains the least amount of energy.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The rate of photosynthesis is highest when exposed to combined light in the 650 nm and 700 nm ranges because the combination of the two wavelengths of light contains the greatest amount of energy.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The rate of photosynthesis is highest when exposed to combined light in the 650 nm and 700 nm ranges because there are two photosystems in chloroplasts that absorb light in two different wavelengths.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The amount of energy in light is inversely proportional to its wavelength. The shorter the wavelength of light, the more energy it contains. The lines on the graph that are closest to the x-axis represent the greatest amount of reduction and, therefore, the greatest amount of photosynthesis. According to the graph, the most reduction or photosynthesis occurs with two wavelengths of light combined. The reason is that in chloroplasts, two photosystems, P700 and P680, absorb light of different wavelengths.

content:
Today, two distinctly different beak sizes occur in a single population of finch in an isolated region of West Africa. This finch, the black-bellied seedcracker, is considered a delicacy. The oldest residents of the region remember that all black-bellied seedcrackers used to appear identical. The change in population is shown in the graph.

Which of the following statements best identifies the change in the population of finches and the most likely reason for it?

answers.A: <label>A. Convergent evolution; two distinct varieties evolved into one variety because only one type of seed now exists.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Diversifying selection; one population of finch divided into two populations because at least two types of seeds are now available.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Directional selection; one original variety was replaced by another because one food source was replaced by another.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Stabilizing selection; the original population died out, leaving only individuals with either long or short beak size.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) There used to be one population of black-bellied seedcracker; now there are two. The single population diverged because of a change in food.

content:
Here is a figure showing the change in one ancestral population of birds over time.

Which of the following statements best supports the evidence presented in the picture?

answers.A: <label>A. Evolution was gradual and regular with small changes over a long period of time.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The environment stayed the same for long periods of time.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. These birds evolved from a single species that went extinct.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. These birds evolved mainly as a result of genetic drift.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The y-axis shows time. The change you see in the birds is sudden. It is not gradual and slow. It occured suddenly. The environment directs evolution. So if a species remains the same for a long time, one can assume that the environment has not changed for all that time. The ancestral species is still alive; it did not go extinct. None of the information leads you to think that evolution occurred because of genetic drift.

content: Which of the following statements is correct about the DNA content of a particular diploid cell just prior to mitosis if the DNA content of the same diploid cell in G1 is X?

answers.A: <label>A. The DNA content of the cell in metaphase I is 0.5X</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The DNA content of the cell in metaphase I is X.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The DNA content of the cell in metaphase I is 2X.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The DNA content of the cell in metaphase I is 4X.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The cell cycle consists in order of G1 (the cell is growing), S (DNA replicates), G2 (second gap of growth), and then mitosis (division of the nucleus). Therefore, if G1 is X (before the S phase), then in mitosis (after the S phase), the DNA content must be double X or 2X.

content: Which of the following sketches shows the correct way in which two nucleotides pair up in a molecule of DNA?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) There is a double hydrogen bond between adenine and thymine in DNA and a triple bond between cytosine and guanine. Breaks in DNA occur more often between adenine and thymine than between cytosine and guanine.

content: Which of the following statements is correct about the plant cell structure shown?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This is a chloroplast. The light-dependent reactions, where ATP is synthesized and oxygen is released, occurs in the grana (C). The light-independent reactions, where PGAL is made, occur in the stroma (B). Nothing related to photosynthesis is occurring in A, which is the outer membrane of the chloroplast.

content: Except for identical twins, no two people are genetically identical. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the main source of variation in humans?

answers.A: <label>A. The main source of variation in humans is genetic drift.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Changes in the environment cause rapid changes in different human populations.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Shuffling of alleles is responsible for the greatest variation in humans.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Mutations are responsible for the greatest changes in different human populations.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) More than anything else, sexual reproduction with recombination of alleles is the greatest source of variation in humans. Genetic drift and mutation are also an important source of variation in humans, but they do not provide nearly as much variation as does recombination of alleles. Changes in the environment provide pressure for evolution, but they are not a source for variation.

content:
β-thalassemia is a disease that strikes mainly people of Mediterranean and Asian descent. It involves a flaw in the gene that codes for β-globin, one of the protein chains that make up hemoglobin (Hb). A trial was conducted. The patient in this trial was typical of individuals with β-thalassemia. He needed monthly blood transfusions and daily treatments to lower blood iron levels. In 2007, when the patient was 19 years old, scientists removed some of his bone marrow cells and treated them with a modified virus that was engineered to carry a good copy of the β-globin gene. They infused the repaired cells into the patient. After several months, the scientists assessed the patient. Here is a graph of the results.

Which of the following statements is supported by the information provided?

answers.B: <label>B. The gene therapy trial was a success, but the patient still requires blood transfusions.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Researchers transplanted a gene directly into the patient's red blood cells.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Researchers inserted a gene into a virus vector that carried the normal hemoglobin gene into the patient's cells.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This was a very successful treatment. The patient's hemoglobin (Hb) levels are approaching normal levels. There are no sudden and severe drops in Hb levels, and the patient no longer requires transfusions.

content:
This graph represents three idealized survivorship curves for different populations.

Which of the following statements correctly explains the information shown on this graph?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Line A describes the survivorship curve for mammals like humans: few offspring, much parental care, and death at old age. Line C is characteristic of external fertilizers, like sea stars, where there is enormous predation of young. Line B is characteristic of a population that is vulnerable throughout its life but is not particularly vulnerable at any one stage more than at any others.

content:
The agave, or century plant, generally grows in arid climates with unpredictable rainfall and poor soil. The plant exhibits what is commonly called big bang reproduction. An agave grows for years, accumulating nutrients in its tissues until there is an unusually wet year. Then it sends up a large flowering stalk, produces seeds, and dies.

Which of the following statements gives the most likely explanation for how the agave plant has evolved this unusual life strategy?

answers.A: <label>A. This strategy is determined by the plant's genes, which are inherited.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. This particular life strategy was selected for by the harsh, desert environment.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. This strategy is the result of a series of mutations that occurred because of the great heat in the desert.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. This strategy is the result of a series of mutations that occurred because of the great heat in addition to the lack of rain in the desert.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Choices C and D have the theory backward. Mutations may provide variety in a population, but they do not occur to provide a variety or a solution to a problem. Mutations occur. If they are advantageous, that new characteristic may increase in frequency in a population. If they are deleterious, that trait may disappear.

content: Which of the following statements is NOT correct about apoptosis?

answers.A: <label>A. Apoptosis, a special type of cell division, requires multiple cell signaling.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The fact that apoptosis is widespread across several kingdoms is evidence that it evolved early in the evolution of eukaryotes.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Apoptosis plays a crucial role in the development of fingers in embryonic development.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Apoptosis prevents an aging and dying cell from damaging neighboring cells.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The question states NOT. Every choice is correct about apoptosis except Choice A. Apoptosis is programmed cell death, not a form of cell division.

content:
Here are drawings of four amino acids.

Molecule A is serine and has polar side chains. Molecule B is lysine, which is basic and positively charged. Molecule C, glutamate, is acidic and negatively charged. Molecule D is glycine. It has nonpolar side chains.

Which of the following statements is correct about these amino acids?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) In general, substances that are polar and/or charged cannot diffuse through a membrane; only nonpolar molecules can.

content: Which of the following statements describes the structural level of a protein that is least affected by hydrogen bonding?

answers.A: <label>A. Primary structure depends on the sequence of amino acids.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Tertiary structure has a shape dependent on the interactions of side chains of amino acids.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Quaternary structure results from the aggregation of more than one polypeptide unit.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. An α-helix is an example of a secondary structure of a polypeptide.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Hydrogen bonding determines secondary and tertiary structure but not primary.

content: Which of the following characteristics would allow you to distinguish a prokaryotic cell from an animal cell?

answers.C: <label>C. Chloroplasts</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Cell wall</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Cell walls are present in prokaryotes but not eukaryotic animal cells. Ribosomes and cell membranes are present in both of them. Chloroplasts and large central vacuoles are not seen in either of them. Animal cells have small vacuoles.

content: Which of the following is the source of oxygen produced during photosynthesis?

answers.C: <label>C. CO<sub>2</sub></label>
answers.D: <label>D. CO</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-The oxygen released by plants is produced during the light reactions of photosynthesis. The main inputs to the light reactions are water and light. Water is the source of the oxygen.

content: An organism exposed to wild temperature fluctuations shows very little, if any, change in its metabolic rate. This organism is most probably a

answers.C: <label>C. thermophyle.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. ascospore.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-Endotherms are organisms whose metabolic rates do not respond to shifts in environmental temperature.

content: Which of the following is a frameshift mutation?

answers.A: <label>A. CAT HAS HIS → CAT HAS HIT</label>
answers.B: <label>B. CAT HAS HIS → CAT HSH ISA</label>
answers.C: <label>C. CAT HAS HIS → CAT HIS HAT</label>
answers.D: <label>D. CAT HAS HIS → CAT WAS HIT</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-A frameshift mutation is one in which the reading frame for the protein construction machinery is shifted. It is a deletion or addition of nucleotides in a number that is not a multiple of 3. Often this can lead to premature stop codons, which lead to nonfunctional proteins.

content: A researcher conducts a survey of a biome and finds 35 percent more species than she has found in any other biome. Which biome is she most likely to be in?

answers.C: <label>C. Tropical rainforest</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Temperate deciduous forest</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C

content: On the basis of the following crossover frequencies, determine the relative location of these four genes:
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-We can see from the data that m and f have the highest crossover frequency. They must therefore be farthest apart of any pair along the chromosome. This leaves only answer choice C.

content: A man contracts the same flu strain for the second time in a single winter season. The second time he experiences fewer symptoms and recovers more quickly. Which cells are responsible for this rapid recovery?

answers.C: <label>C. Memory cells</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Plasma cells</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Memory B cells are able to recognize foreign invaders if they come back into our systems and lead to a more rapid and efficient attack on the invader.

content: Which of the following are traits that are affected by more than one gene?

answers.C: <label>C. Polygenic traits</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Blended alleles</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Polygenic traits are traits that require the input of multiple genes to determine the phenotype. Skin color is a classic example of a polygenic trait; three genes combine to provide the various shades of skin tone seen in humans.

content: A lizard lacking a chemical defense mechanism that is colored in the same way as a lizard that has a defense mechanism is displaying

answers.C: <label>C. Batesian mimicry.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Müllerian mimicry.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-This is a classic example of Batesian mimicry.

content: Crossover would most likely occur in which situation?

answers.A: <label>A. Two genes (1 and 2) are located right next to each other on chromosome A.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Gene 1 is located on chromosome A, and gene 2 is on chromosome B.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Genes 1 and 2 are located near each other on the X chromosome.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Gene 1 is located on chromosome A; gene 2 is located far away but on the same chromosome.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Crossover is most likely to occur between two genes that are located far away from each other on the same chromosome.

content: Imagine an organism whose 2n = 96. Meiosis would leave this organism’s cells with how many chromosomes?

answers.C: <label>C. 48</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 24</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Meiosis reduces the number of chromosomes in an individual by half: 96 รท 2 = 48.

content: A student conducts an experiment to test the efficiency of a certain enzyme. Which of the following protocols would probably not result in a change in the enzyme’s efficiency?

answers.A: <label>A. Bringing the temperature of the experimental setup from 20°C to 50°C</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Adding an acidic solution to the setup</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Adding substrate but not enzyme</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Placing the substrate and enzyme in a container with double the capacity</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-The volume of the container is not a major factor that affects enzyme efficiency.

content: You observe a species that gives birth to only one offspring at a time and has a relatively long life-span for its body size. Which of the following is probably also true of this organism?

answers.A: <label>A. It lives in a newly colonized habitat.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It requires relatively high parental care of offspring.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The age at which the offspring themselves can give birth is relatively young.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-The original question describes an organism that can be classified as a K-selected population. Individuals of this class tend to have fairly constant size, low reproductive rates, and offspring that require extensive care.

content: Which of the following is an example of a detritivore?

answers.C: <label>C. Bat</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Fungus</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-A detritivore is an organism that includes the subcategory of decomposers. Fungi are decomposers.

content: In a certain population of squirrels that is in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, black color is a recessive phenotype present in 9 percent of the squirrels, and 91 percent are gray. What percentage of the population is homozygous dominant for this trait?

answers.C: <label>C. 49 percent</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 70 percent</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-If 9 percent of the population is homozygous recessive, this means that q2 = 0.09, and that the square root of q2 = 0.30 = q. This means that p = 0.70 since p + q = 1. Thus, the percentage of the population that is homozygous dominant: p2 = (0.7)2 = 0.49 or 49 percent.

content: Refer to question 15 for details on the squirrel population. Which of the following conditions is required to keep this population in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium?

answers.C: <label>C. Mutation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Gene flow</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-All the other answer choices are violations of the Hardy - Weinberg equilibrium.

content: A reaction that includes energy as one of its reactants is called a(n)

answers.C: <label>C. endergonic reaction.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. redox reaction.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Exergonic reactions give off energy, and hydrolysis reactions are reactions that use water to break apart a compound. Redox reactions are reactions that involve the movement of electrons. Dehydration reactions are reactions that bring two molecules together, releasing water as a product.

content: To which of the following labeled trophic levels would a herbivore most likely be assigned?

answers.C: <label>C. C</label>
answers.D: <label>D. D</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Herbivores tend to be the primary consumers of trophic pyramids, and thus would take up the first level up from the bottom.

content: A population undergoes a shift in which those who are really tall and those who are really short decrease in relative frequency compared to those of medium size, due to a change in the availability of resources. This is an example of

answers.C: <label>C. disruptive selection.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. sympatric speciation.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-Stabilizing selection tends to eliminate the extremes of a population, directional selection is a shift toward one of the extremes, and disruptive selection is the camel-hump selection in which the two extremes are favored over the middle. Sympatric speciation is the formation of new species due to an inability to reproduce that is not caused by geographic separation. Sexual selection is evolution of characters that aid in mate acquisition.

content: Which of the following statements is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. Water flows from hypertonic to hypotonic.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Germinating seeds use less oxygen than do nongerminating seeds.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The rate of transpiration decreases with an increase in air movement.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Smaller DNA fragments migrate more rapidly than do larger DNA fragments on gel electrophoresis.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-We threw it in here just to remind you that you should not ignore the concepts of this very important chapter. You will be asked about these concepts on the exam.

content: Which of the following is not a form of interspecies interaction?

answers.C: <label>C. Mutualism</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Parasitism</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-Succession is an ecological process in which landforms evolve over time in response to the environmental conditions. Commensalism is when one organism benefits while the other is unaffected. Mutualism is when both organisms reap benefits from the interaction. Parasitism is when one organism benefits at the other's expense. Competition is the situation in which organisms fight for some limited resource.

content: Sickle cell anemia is a disease caused by the substitution of an incorrect nucleotide into the DNA sequence for a particular gene. The amino acids are still added to the growing protein chain, but the symptoms of sickle cell anemia result. This is an example of a

answers.C: <label>C. nonsense mutation.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. thymine dimer mutation.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B

content:
A behavioral endocrinologist captures male individuals of a territorial bird species over the course of a year to measure testosterone (T) levels. In this population, males may play one of two roles: (1) they may stay in their natal group (the group they were born in) and help raise their younger siblings, or (2) they may leave the natal group to establish a new territory. Use this information and the two histograms that follow to answer the following questions.

Testosterone level in this population may be an example of

answers.C: <label>C. divergent selection.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. development.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-Testosterone level is an adaptive trait in this population, one that has been molded by natural selection (or possibly sexual selection; we cannot determine this from the question) to aid in reproduction. Adaptive radiation is a process by which many speciation events occur in a newly exploited environment and does not apply here. This is not an example of divergent selection because both breeding and nonbreeding males have low testosterone levels during at least one part of the year; if the two male types always differed in testosterone level, this population could eventually split into two populations. Development and sperm production may be related to testosterone but are not addressed in this experiment.

content:
A behavioral endocrinologist captures male individuals of a territorial bird species over the course of a year to measure testosterone (T) levels. In this population, males may play one of two roles: (1) they may stay in their natal group (the group they were born in) and help raise their younger siblings, or (2) they may leave the natal group to establish a new territory. Use this information and the two histograms that follow to answer the following questions.

What can you infer about the role of testosterone in reproduction in this species?

answers.C: <label>C. It ensures that all males reproduce equally.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It aids in breeding.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Since testosterone levels are increased only during the breeding season, we can infer that testosterone has some role in breeding. Since reproductive males express higher testosterone levels only during the breeding season, we hypothesize that testosterone is beneficial, as opposed to detrimental, to breeding.

content: Which of the following is the best explanation of the results presented in the preceding graph, collected from the same population in a different year?

answers.A: <label>A. The so-called helper males are actually breeding.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Females are equally attracted to adult and helper males.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Testosterone level is affected by many processes.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Since testosterone seems to be linked with reproduction, we infer from the new data that the "nonbreeding" males are actually breeding and therefore have elevated testosterone levels. Females, population growth, and number of offspring produced are not considered in this example. Finally, although testosterone does affect many physiological processes, none of these are discussed or illustrated in this example.

content:
A researcher grows a population of ferns in her laboratory. She notices, after a few generations, a new variant that has a distinct phenotype. When she tries to breed the original phenotype with the new one, no offspring are produced. When she breeds the new variants, however, offspring that look like the new variant result.

What originally caused the change in the variant?

answers.C: <label>C. Mutation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Polyploidy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Although several processes can affect the frequency of a new phenotype or genotype, once it is in place, the original genetic change must have been the result of a mutation (probably a chromosomal aberration).

content:
A researcher grows a population of ferns in her laboratory. She notices, after a few generations, a new variant that has a distinct phenotype. When she tries to breed the original phenotype with the new one, no offspring are produced. When she breeds the new variants, however, offspring that look like the new variant result.

What kind of speciation does this example illustrate?

answers.C: <label>C. Isolated</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Polyploidy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-No physical barrier separated the two populations; this is therefore an example of sympatric, not allopatric speciation. The other answer choices are not types of speciation.

content:
A researcher grows a population of ferns in her laboratory. She notices, after a few generations, a new variant that has a distinct phenotype. When she tries to breed the original phenotype with the new one, no offspring are produced. When she breeds the new variants, however, offspring that look like the new variant result.

Which of the following could possibly characterize the new variant?

answers.C: <label>C. Equilibrium</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Polyploidy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Polyploidy is the only answer that can describe an individual. All the others are processes or states that describe population events. Polyploidy is the duplication of whole chromosomes that leads to speciation because the new variety can no longer breed with the original.

content:
A researcher grows a population of ferns in her laboratory. She notices, after a few generations, a new variant that has a distinct phenotype. When she tries to breed the original phenotype with the new one, no offspring are produced. When she breeds the new variants, however, offspring that look like the new variant result.

Which of the following is likely to exhibit the process described earlier?

answers.C: <label>C. Grass</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Spotted toads</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Polyploidy is much more common in plants; mutations such as the duplication of whole chromosomes are usually lethal to animals.

content: The DNA placed in this electrophoresis gel separates as a result of what characteristic?

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Gel electrophoresis separates DNA on the basis of size. Smaller samples travel a greater distance down the gel compared to larger samples.

content: If this gel were used in a court case as DNA evidence taken from the crime scene, which of the following suspects appears to be guilty?

content:

content:
The frequency of genotypes for a given trait are given in the accompanying graph. Answer the following questions using this information:

What would be the approximate frequency of the heterozygote condition if this population were in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium?

answers.C: <label>C. 48 percent</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 72 percent</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-36 percent of the population is AA. Taking the square root of 0.36, we find the frequency of the A allele to be 0.6. This means that the a allele's frequency must be 1 - 0.6, or 0.4. From these numbers, we can calculate the expected Hardy-Weinberg heterozygous frequency is 2pq = 2(A)(a) = 2(0.6)(0.4) = 48.0 or 48 percent.

content:

B-The expected heterozygous probability does not match up with the actual. This population is not in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

content:

content:
An eager AP Biology student interested in studying osmosis and the movement of water in solutions took a dialysis bag containing a 0.5 M solution and placed it into a beaker containing a 0.6 M solution.

After the bag has been sitting in the beaker for a while, what would you expect to have happened to the bag?

answers.A: <label>A. There will have been a net flow of water out of the bag, causing it to decrease in size.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There will be have been a net flow of water into the bag, causing it to swell in size.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The bag will be the exact same size because no water will have moved at all.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The solute will have moved out of the dialysis bag into the beaker.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Water will flow out of the bag because the solute concentration of the beaker is hypertonic compared to the dialysis bag. Osmosis passively drives water from a hypotonic region to a hypertonic region.

content:
An eager AP Biology student interested in studying osmosis and the movement of water in solutions took a dialysis bag containing a 0.5 M solution and placed it into a beaker containing a 0.6 M solution.

If this bag were instead placed into a beaker of distilled water, what would be the expected result?

answers.A: <label>A. There will be a net flow of water out of the bag, causing it to decrease in size.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There will be a net flow of water into the bag, causing it to swell in size.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The bag will remain the exact same size because no water will move at all.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The solute will flow out of the dialysis bag into the beaker.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-Water would now flow into the bag because the solute gradient has been reversed. Now the beaker is hypotonic compared to the dialysis bag. Water thus moves into the bag.

content:
An eager AP Biology student interested in studying osmosis and the movement of water in solutions took a dialysis bag containing a 0.5 M solution and placed it into a beaker containing a 0.6 M solution.

Which of the following is true about water potential?

answers.A: <label>A. It drives the movement of water from a region of lower water potential to a region of higher water potential.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Solute potential is the only factor that determines the water potential.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Pressure potential combines with solute potential to determine the water potential.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Water potential = pressure potential + solute potential. Water passively moves from regions with high water potential toward those with lower water potential.

content:
Questions all use the following pedigree, but are independent of each other:

If the pedigree is studying an autosomal recessive condition for which the alleles are A and a, what was the probability that a child produced by parents A and B would be heterozygous?

answers.C: <label>C. 0.2500</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 0.5000</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-The mother (person B) must be heterozygous Aa because she and her husband (aa) have produced children that have the double recessive condition. This means that person B (the mother) must have contributed an a and that the cross is Aa Ã—aa-and the probability is 1/2.

content:
Questions all use the following pedigree, but are independent of each other:

Imagine that a couple (C and D) go to a genetic counselor because they are interested in having children. They tell the counselor that they have a family history of a certain disorder and they want to know the probability of their firstborn having this condition. What is the probability of the child having the autosomal recessive condition?

answers.C: <label>C. 0.2500</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 0.3333</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-To answer this question, we must first determine the probability that person D is heterozygous. We know she is not aa because she does not have the condition. Since we know that the father has the condition, we know for certain that his genotype is aa. Both of mother D's parents must be heterozygous since neither of them have the condition, but they have produced a child with the condition. The probability that mother D is heterozygous Aa is 2/3. The probability that a couple with the genotypes Aa ×aa have a double recessive child is 1/2. The probability that these two will have a child with the condition is 1/2 ×2/3 = 1/3 = 0.333.

content:
Questions all use the following pedigree, but are independent of each other:

Imagine that a couple (C and D) have a child (E) that has the autosomal recessive condition being traced by the pedigree. What is the probability that their second child (F) will have the autosomal recessive condition?

answers.C: <label>C. 0.2500</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 0.5000</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E-If the couple has a child (person E) with the recessive condition, then we know for certain that mother D must be heterozygous. It is definitely an aa Ã—Aa cross, leaving a 50 percent chance that their child will be aa.

content:
The solutions in the two arms of this U-tube are separated by a membrane that is permeable to water and sodium chloride, but not to sucrose. Side A is filled with a solution of 0.6 M sucrose and 0.2 M sodium chloride (NaCl), and side B is filled with a solution of 0.2 M sucrose and 0.3 M NaCl. Initially, the volume on both sides is the same.

At the beginning of the experiment,

answers.A: <label>A. Side A is hypertonic to side B.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Side A is hypotonic to side B.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Side A is isotonic to side B.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Side A is hypotonic to side B with respect to sucrose.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-The total solute potential for side A is 1.0 MPa (remember that for NaCl, i = 2), and the total solute potential for side B is 0.8 MPa. Therefore, side A has a higher concentration of solute (hypertonic).

content:
The solutions in the two arms of this U-tube are separated by a membrane that is permeable to water and sodium chloride, but not to sucrose. Side A is filled with a solution of 0.6 M sucrose and 0.2 M sodium chloride (NaCl), and side B is filled with a solution of 0.2 M sucrose and 0.3 M NaCl. Initially, the volume on both sides is the same.

If you examine side A after a couple of days, you will see

answers.A: <label>A. an increase in the concentration of NaCl and sucrose and an increase in water level.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a decrease in the concentration of NaCl, an increase in water level, and no change in the concentration of sucrose.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. no net change.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. an increase in the concentration of NaCl and an increase in the water level.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Water will move from a hypotonic solution (side B) toward a hypertonic solution (side A). Sodium will diffuse from a region of more sodium (side B) to a region of less sodium (side A).

content: Tay-Sachs is a disease caused by a recessive allele. Individuals with the genetic disorder usually do not survive more than a few years, and thus are not able to reproduce and pass on the gene. What would explain how this allele and its associated disease is preserved in the population?

answers.A: <label>A. Heterozygous individuals will show no symptoms.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Spontaneous mutation converts the dominant allele to the recessive form.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Occasionally the gene will instead increase the fitness of the individual.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Tay-Sachs is asymptomatic in people who are homozygous recessive.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Heterozygous individuals carry the recessive gene but are themselves healthy.

content: A new plant was discovered and determined to have an unusually low number of stomata on the undersides of its leaves. For what environment would this plant most likely be best adapted?

answers.C: <label>C. Hot and humid</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Hot and dry</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Low numbers of stomata help to reduce water loss, helpful in hot and dry regions.

content: The first simple cells evolved approximately 3.5 billion years ago, followed by the more complex eukaryotic cells 2.1 billion years ago. Which of the following statements is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. Eukaryotic organelles helped create separate environments for metabolic reactions, thus increasing their metabolic efficiency.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have no structural similarities.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The organelles in larger eukaryotic cells took care of the problems of having a larger surface area–to–volume ratio.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Eukaryotic cells are able to multiply faster based on their more complex structure.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells do have similar structures, the organelles in eukaryotic cells took care of having a smaller surface area-to-volume ratio, and eukaryotic cells are not able to multiply faster.

content: Easily produced genetic variation is key to the rapid evolution of viral and microbial populations. Furthermore, pathogens that need to escape the immune system rely on this variation to generate new surface antigens that go unrecognized by the host’s immune system. Which of the following is an example of this antigenic variation?

answers.A: <label>A. HIV, which can remain integrated into the host genome for many years</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The flu virus, which changes its envelope proteins</label>
answers.C: <label>C. MRSA, which has become resistant to many antibiotics</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Multiple sclerosis, which attacks the cells of the nervous system</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-Changing envelope proteins are created because of genetic variation in the genes that code for these proteins.

content: Two species of hamster (X and Y) are in the genus Cricetulus, whereas a third species (Z) is instead part of genus Mesocricetus. Which of the following phylogenetic trees shows the correct evolutionary relatedness?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-This cladogram shows a closer relationship between X and Y.

content: A baby duck runs for cover when a large object is tossed over its head. After this object is repeatedly passed overhead, the duck learns there is no danger and stops running for cover when the same object appears again. This is an example of

answers.C: <label>C. agonistic behavior.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. habituation.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Habituation is the loss of responsiveness to unimportant stimuli or stimuli that do not provide appropriate feedback. This is a prime example of habituation.

content: In a population of giraffes, an environmental change occurs that favors individuals that are tallest. As a result, more of the taller individuals are able to obtain nutrients and survive to pass along their genetic information. This is an example of

answers.C: <label>C. sexual selection.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. disruptive selection.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Directional selection occurs when members of a population at one end of a spectrum are selected against, while those at the other end are selected for. Taller giraffes are being selected for; shorter giraffes are being selected against.

content: The relatives of a group of pelicans from the same species that separated from each other because of an unsuccessful migration are reunited 150 years later and find that they are unable to produce offspring. This is an example of

answers.C: <label>C. genetic drift.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. gene flow.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-When interbreeding ceases because some sort of barrier separates a single population into two (an area with no food, a mountain, etc.), the two populations evolve independently, and if they change enough, then, even if the barrier is removed, they cannot interbreed. This is allopatric speciation.

content: A cell is placed into a hypertonic environment and its cytoplasm shrivels up. This demonstrates the principle of

content: In a certain pond, there are long-finned fish and short-finned fish. A horrific summer thunderstorm leads to the death of a disproportionate number of long-finned fish to the point where the relative frequency of the two forms has drastically shifted. This is an example of

content: You are told that in a population of guinea pigs, 4 percent are black (recessive) and 96 percent are brown. Which of the following is the frequency of the heterozygous condition?

answers.C: <label>C. 40 percent</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 48 percent</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-0.04 = q2. Therefore, the square root of 0.04 = q = 0.20 and p + q = 1. So p + 0.20 = 1. Therefore, p = 0.80, and 2pq is the frequency of the heterozygote condition: 2(0.20)(0.80) = 0.320 = 32 percent.

content: Which of the following is known to be involved in the photoperiodic flowering response of angiosperms?
